text:
Five stars and an A+. This is the perfect basic sloppy joes recipe. I won't be buying the canned stuff anymore. We like ours just a little stickier so added 1/2 cup water and a tablespoon of quick oats then simmered it down. MMM  Next time I'm going to double it so I can freeze the extra. I fill the cups in a muffin tin with the leftovers and freeze. When frozen just pop them out and store in a Ziploc bag in the freezer. Each one is the perfect size for a bun and ready to microwave at a seconds notice.

text:
Much better than Manwich and SO easy!  The best thing is it's made with ingredients I always have in the house and it's not a hundred ingredients either so it's fast to make.  I always make more sauce than it calls for, I think it's too dry otherwise.  If I make it with 1 lb. of meat I double the sauce, 2 lbs. I triple it, 3 lbs. I quadruple it, etc.  It's great in the crockpot too; I make it in the morning when I have a minute and it sits in the crockpot on low all day.  I've passed this recipe on to anyone who will take it.

text:
Absolutely delicious. This is the perfect recipe for sloppy joes in my opinion. People complain about the reviews being overrated because this isn't all jazzed-up into something special. Well what do you expect, it's only sloppy joes! I haven't had sloppy joes in years, and I am so glad I chose this recipe to finally have a taste of some. The only thing I would definitely change is the simmer time. Even on the lowest fire I had to cut it down to 20 min. instead of the original 30 because it started sticking to the pan. But it was finished by then any way and the flavors have already come out from the seasonings. This was AWESOME! A definite keeper. If you would like to simmer for the full 30 min, follow the advice of others and add just a bit of water and/or extra ketchup. This also adds more sloppiness. Yum!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful, easy basic recipe, as the high ratings can attest.  However, for those who tend to find this too sweet, don't add the brown sugar until the last, at the same time you adjust the S&P. If you find it doesn't need the sugar, skip it; or add just a tiny bit at a time until you like it.  Or try 1/2-1 tsp. molasses instead of the br. sugar to add depth of flavor without much sweetness.  

Still too sweet? You might also need to substitute tomato sauce for the ketchup (in which case you might want to add a bit of additional spices.) 

If you have already made the recipe as listed, and find it too sweet, DON'T THROW IT OUT!  Remember that acids are sour and will offset the sweetness. Therefore, add a splash of vinegar or unsweetened tomato products (such as tomato paste or chopped tomatoes) a little at a time until the sweetness is corrected to your tastes. Then follow the steps above next time you make this.

Don't pass up this quick, easy, tasty recipe without tweaking it to suit your family's tastes! :)

This one always makes EVERYone happy!  :)  I add a tsp of liquid smoke, 1/2 c. bbq sauce and a tbsp of apple cider vinegar for a little zing.  Then I mix a little mayo, garlic salt & parmesan cheese & spread it onto the buns.  Add jack cheese to one side & broil until bubbley, then top with sloppy joe.  A favorite in our house for sure! text:
These sloppy joes immediately moved into first place at our house, knocking my once-favorite recipe out of the running! Everyone loved the not-too-sweet, not-too-tangy flavor and rich, thick consistency. I made it exactly as directed and wouldn't change a thing! To save time, I prepare the mixture several hours ahead of time and keep it warm in a slow-cooker until dinner. I have also tried quadrupling the recipe for a crowd and it works great, affecting neither flavor nor texture.

text:
Everyone is right, this is a winner!
I made two batches today using 6 lbs. of ground chuck in each batch. I stock the freezer for future use.  To cut the fat, I cook just the meat and then pour very hot water over it and drain. Next, I added the  raw onion & peppers and the remaining ingredients and simmer for a couple of hours.  There is so much flavor going on that you'll never miss the fat.

text:
Added a couple Tablespoons of hubby's favorite BBQ sauce, a teaspoon of Goya Seasonings, a couple dashes of Chili Powder and a couple teaspoons of Worcestershire Sauce, I used red bell pepper instead of green, and used 2t of brown sugar instead of 3 and instead of Garlic Powder, I used 2 minced fresh cloves of garlic and added that after the meat, onion and pepper were cooked and drained so as not to burn the garlic and simmered covered only 20 minutes instead of 30.  So freaking good!  My husband said its the best Sloppy Joe's he has ever had and me too!  Thanks for this basic recipe with all ingredients usually on hand!  Love it and love this recipe!  Will be a regular in our rotation!

I don't know what I did wrong here but I could not get any "sauce" to be made. My meat kept sucking up everything.  I doubled the recipe and ended up using an entire bottle of ketchup then adding water and letting it cook down over and over again.  Finally I got some sauce and my husband said it would be 5-star if it had just a bit more "glue" to hold the meat together.  The flavor profiles were there and it was excellent, I just had issues with the sauce.  Will continue to practice with this because it is too good to not make again, I am just puzzled about my sauce.  Great flavors - 4 teenage boys wolfed them down.

text:
My family loves sloppy joes while i'm not a complete fan.  I absolutely despise the canned stuff so decided to try this recipe.  I used about 1.5lbs of meat for this and i doubled the green peppers in it.  I seasoned the meat while cooking, as i would with any other recipe and i used 3 cloves of fresh minced garlic as well.  I pretty much doubled the sauce, using 1.5c ketchup and about 3/4 c bbq sauce.  I only used the 3tbsp of brown sugar though as i found doubling that would have made it far too sweet.  I didn't simmer near the time it says too as it was thickening quite quickly even on lowest heat.  I served these on fresh kaiser buns with freshly diced onions and green pepper and grated cheese for toppers.  Will definitely use this recipe again when my family wants sloppy joes.  Thanks for sharing!
Review:
Rating:
1

text:
Better than mom's.  I combined a lot of the advice given in the reviews. 
-I made sauce first and let it simmer until finished everything else.
-I added 3 tsp of white vinegar.
-I eyeballed some chili powder, which i thought gave the sauce an excellent kick.
-I cut back some of the ketchup with bbq sauce instead.
-I went a little over on the sauce ingredients (and added a little water) to make it extra sloppy.

-If you live in Texas this is 3 servings.  See "Texas Sized" buns. :D

text:
Great as is, I only made small changes after tasting too suit my tastes.  I added 1 tsp of Worcestershire, an additional 1 tsp of prepared yellow mustard, and 1 tsp of onion powder, in addition to the other spices that the recipe called for.  Tastes like Manwich, just without the canned taste and a little sweeter.  If you tend to like your Sloppy Joes not on the sweet side, then I would recommend starting out with only 1 tsp of brown sugar and then you can add more if you like.

This was a very good, slightly tangy recipe. After reading others' reviews that it wasn't "sloppy" enough, I added a cup of beef broth, and simmered it for a bit longer. It turned out just the right consistency. This must've also helped cut down the sweetness, as, unlike some other reviewers, I didn't find it to be too sweet at all. I also omitted the green peppers to make it more kid friendly.

text:
If you like your sloppy joe sweet, this is for you! I had to improvise a bit, but did my best: Added 1/8 tsp cayanne pepper & 1 tsp A1 sauce, didn't have green pepper so doubled onion. This is a good basic recipe, & worth working with, but came out too sweet for my taste so next time I'm adding 1/4 tsp cayanne & cutting the sugar -- ketchup is sweet enough.  **UPDATE** Made this again without any brown sugar & kept the A-1 sauce, no cayanne; turned out better for me/less sweet. I'm going to keep tweaking this one. It's VERY FORGIVING & tastey, I just need to find the perfect blend of kick & just a bit of sweetness!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great starting out recipe for Sloppy Joe's, but it does need some tweaking to be considered worthy of 5 stars, so therefore it just gets 4 from me. Here are my suggestions... if you're going to use ketchup, I would definitely add a package of dry Chili Seasoning Mix, OR use bottled Chili Sauce instead and skip the ketchup altogether. Also, the ratio is off a bit; I'd use 1/2 cup ketchup & double the amount of mustard. I like to add some Worcestershire as well... probably about a tablespoon. Everyone has their own personal tastes for Sloppy Joe's so just keep on tasting it as you mix it up and you can adjust it to your liking. As I said though, this is a good "starting point recipe" so do give it a try!

text:
Like Whoa...Flavorful! The flavors come out so well in this sandwich, I was pleasantly surprised. Like Emeril though I had to kick it up a notch by adding some hot sauce baby - BAM, BAM, BAM because I like it a little spicy. You know as a kid I grew up on sloppy joe's out of the can like most folks - but as I got older I shyed away from it because of the sweet flavor. But with this recipe you have the ability to control the sweetness it is not oversweet at all. I was expecting a typical tomato-o-e base. No, not at all these ingredients lend itself more to a sort of delicious barbeque flavor. I was like oh snap... she might be on to something here - It simple, quick and easy to make and it fills a hungry belly. Most people already have these ingredients in their pantry already. I Luv it. Indeed a keeper - I will make this again. Beautiful presentation - Reveiwers you have to try this.

country:
None
text:
Absolutely a 5 star recipe. The next-day leftovers are even better! You MUST double the sauce ingredients (garlic powder, mustard, ketchup & brown sugar) because even after simmering for 30 min they're still not very "sloppy". Another MUST is to simmer on the stovetop. My friend loved the recipe so I shared it with her, but she made it in her crockpot. Hers definitely came out sloppier, but the simmering time really makes that brown sugar kind of caramelize, and without that hers just didn't taste as good. My husband hates manwich, so I had to go in search of a recipe he would like... now he gets SO excited every time I tell him we're having sloppy joes for dinner!

text:
Wow. I was so excited about this recipe and SO disappointed in its outcome. With so many positive reviews, I thought for sure it had to be good.  I admit that I goofed up at first, having misread the recipe to say 3 T of brown sugar instead of 3t. Yes, that was incredibly sweet :). I then decided I'd try again, only this time omitting the sugar all together until I tasted it. Well, in my opinion it was still way over the top sweet! I ended up rinsing the meat and going with Manwich, only because I didn't want to waste all that burger. I will search for a recipe that does not claim to be sweet next time around. I have a taste in my mind, but this was not it.

Display Name:
ZENNA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3935683.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is similar to the recipe I make. I use sweet pickle relish instead of green pepper. I do add a tablespoon of brown sugar even though the relish is sweet. To make this ready faster I squirt ketchup and mustard onto the hamburger, add the rest of the ingredients, and fry with medium heat, stirring constantly. To make the Joes a bit less messy, I shake up a teaspoon of flour or cornstarch in a 1/2 cup of water, stir enough of it into the hot mix in the frying pan to moisten, and continue cooking it until the water reduces and the flour or cornstarch are cooked. The hamburger mix is ready to eat at this point.
I use any leftover Sloppy Joe mix in chili or spaghetti sauce: a quick way to make another meal.

text:
This recipe is super basic and I had to change quite a bit, thats why I gave it three stars. My end product was 5 stars in my opinion. I cut this recipe in half for my boyfriend and I (3 servings) Here are the things I changed:
Added 2TBSP jalapeno 
Doubled the garlic (used fresh garlic) 
Only added 1/4 cup of ketchup (used organic ketchup)
Only added 1TSP brown sugar
Added 1/2TSP cumin 
Added 1/4TSP paprika
Added 1/4TSP coriander 
Added 1TBSP broth (chicken, although beef would have been better)

text:
This was very good and super simple; however, we found it to be far too sweet for our tastes (and we didn't even add the brown sugar).  Just as an FYI and basis of comparison for others, it's definitely sweeter than Manwich sauce (and that's not a knock whatsoever against the recipe; we just prefer a less sweet sauce).  We added crushed red pepper flakes to give it a little extra kick, and that was really tasty!  I will definitely make this again, but next time I'm going to try using half ketchup and half tomato sauce/paste so that it won't be quite so sweet.

I only made a couple of small changes to this recipe.  For starters, I doubled the sauce and added a little water to make it a bit saucier. They were so good!  My hubby liked them, and so did my kids.  We hate the canned stuff and I am so glad I came upon this recipe!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is a classic!!!  been making it for 20+ years with these flavors!  For vegetarians or budget stretchers, try using TVP in place of or stretching the meal.  (Been doing it for years and no one complained)  Be sure to reconstitute the TVP with veg broth or beef broth, then add to the simmering part. TVP absorbs too much of the moisture and sauce by itself.  However, if you want a firmer mix,and are using TVP, go less on the broth added to the TVP then add to the sauce. TVP is a wonderful stretcher - and it absorbs the liquids it is in to give a ground meat texture

country:
None
text:
DH and I made this for lunch today and we were less than thrilled...I can't imagine how it's managed to receive so many high reviews!  In the end, it didn't taste horrible, but it didn't taste anything like the canned variety....it was VERY sweet.  We used Heinz ketchup and all the other ingredients which were called for...but we did increase the onion to about 1/2 cup.  In the end, my DH had to add some Worcestershire, more garlic powder, salt and pepper to try to offset the sweetness; there wasn't much improvement.  We likely will not make this again, but I do highly recommend NOT adding any brown sugar until you've tasted the meat mixture...if you still require more sweetness, then add it.

text:
Recipe is good but a few modifications make it great.  I put in just a pinch of brown sugar, next time I won't put in any...ketchup is sweet enough.  I used 1-1/2 pounds of ground beef and added fresh and powdered garlic.  I seasoned it with cracked red pepper, worchester sauce, jalapenos and several shakes of tobasco jalapeno sauce.  I also added one small can of V8 juice and let the flavors absorb while cooking down.  This is more of an adult version - with a little kick.

text:
I had no mustard on hand, so I used about 1 Tbsp of cider vinegar plus 1 tbsp of chilli sauce instead. As suggested by the other reviewers, I also used fresh garlic and added about 2 tbsp of worcestershire sauce. Not wanting it to be too sweet, I used only 1 tsp of brown sugar, but my son said it was not sweet enough, so I added another tsp. The recipe turned out great, and my son said it tasted way better than the packaged mix by Lawry's. Thank you Tamara.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always try a recipe as is first to give it a fair shake... Not fair to rate a recipe if you've changed half the ingredients! I liked this as written, though a touch sweeter than I am used to. But like meatloaf, I change it a little each time! I do always cut back on the brown sugar, but that is the only consistent difference. I have done: half red, half green peppers; added a pinch of cayenne and cumin; a small can of chopped green chilies; a dash of Worcestershire; less ketchup and add some bbq sauce; used spicy brown mustard instead of yellow; a dash of hot sauce; and one of my favorites is to replace 1/4 cup of the ketchup with 1/4 cup of Goya Sofrito. Obviously I don't make all these changes at once, but in different combinations, and sometimes only make one. The point is, start with this basic recipe and tweak it... It's a great starting point! My son even suggested adding a few pieces of crumbled bacon...

Way better than canned sloppy joe mix, hands down and so easy to make.

ren1216

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I appreciate that these are so easy to make and call for ingredients that I always have.  I'm not a big fan of Sloppy Joes, but my BF likes them now and then.  I decided to try this to see if I'd like it better than the typical canned version - I did!  BF said he likes it considerably more.  I made two small changes: I used 1/2c ketchup + 1/4c of my fave bbq sauce, which is sweet, so I reduced the brown sugar by half.  I read other comments about the mixture being too dry, but I covered mine while it simmered and it turned out just right in regards to moisture.  No more canned mix for us - thanks for this recipe.  Update -- for a fun change:  Remove crusts from slices of white break, lightly butter cups of a muffin tin (only the #  you wish to make).  Center bread slice over cup, press down and form into cup.  Fill each bread cup 3/4 full with Sloppy Joe mix, top with some shredded cheddar cheese.  Bake at 350 until bread is light brown and cheese is melted.  The crunch of the toasted bread makes these really good.

I love sloppy joes, they were always my favorite. My mom has this recipe from her great aunt that she always made, well now it was my turn to make my own version. So I used this recipe! My mother is a very picky eater, worse than me, so I was hoping she would like it. And she did! So did I! It was very good, though I could have added some water, tomato sauce, or more ketchup in it to make it more moist. But it was still very good! I will definitely make this again someday!

I followed this recipe exactly as written and was rather disappointed.  I had great expectations for it given the great reviews.  I don't make adjustments to a recipe when I rate it, that's not fair to the recipe in my opinion.  Right before serving it, my husband tried it and said something has to be done to this before eating this...it tastes bland and is very dry (I had not simmered it for more than 20 minutes).  I added more ketchup and more mustard.  I finally got it to be "more sloppy" but I will say that I was still disappointed.  I'm either sticking with Manwich or looking for another recipe...bummer!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this with 2 # ground beef and doubled the rest of ingredients.  I left out the green pepper.  I added diced onion after the meat was browned-we liked the texture and flavor of the onions this way.  I also added a good splash of apple cider vinegar because before that the flavor was just like SWEET ketchup.  IMHO, the apple cider vinegar  made all the difference.  We were in a hurry and just warmed it through without the simmering and it was still flavorful and yummy.  We liked the thickness, as it stayed on the buns well, even piling it high!  Great basic recipe, but adjust sweetness according to your family's likes.  Thanks Tamara!

This is really Great!!!  I tripled the recipe and also used half ketchup and half barbecue sauce.  This is the best sloppy joe we have ever had!

Just a tip:  we had this for lunch with rolls, then for dinner,  I placed the left over on a 9x13 casserole dish, made the "Grandma Buttermilk Cornbread" also from this site, poured on top of the sloppy joe and baked until the corn bread was ready.  Delicious! and great for my meal plan.

text:
I wouldn't call this a Sloppy Joe, it was more a loose meat (think Maid Rite) sandwich. I had to add 1 can of tomato sauce, 2 tablespoons of tomato paste, 1 tablespoon of worcestershire sauce and a little more mustard for this to taste more like Sloppy Joes. I gave 2 stars because, if I ever want to make Maid Rites, I'd add a can of cola and this would be a good recipe.

text:
Soooo good! I like mine saucy so I doubled the garlic and mustard. I also omitted the brown sugar and added in 3/4 C Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory and Brown Sugar BBQ sauce. Two of my kids don't eat well so I threw in a can of V-8, which made it a tad too sweet so I then added a tablespoon or so of white vinegar. As written, it's a great recipe, that my parents later informed me is the very recipe that they've been using since I was a kid. But, I tweaked it this evening for my family's diverse taste buds and, surprisingly, got thumbs up from even the pickiest of children. :)

text:
Yikes!  Way too sweet!  Hubby and I have been low carbing for two years, and things just taste too sweet anymore.  I still gave it four stars because the base recipe is AWESOME and EASY!  Next time I will cut the brown sugar way down, if use it at all.  I took the advice of another person and added Worcestershire sauce and white vinegar.  Nice, zesty addition!  Also tossed in some red pepper flakes, because I enjoy heat.  Also, I didn't think it was soupy enough, so added some tomato sauce and a little bit of water.  By the time it was done simmering, it was the perfect consistency.   I was getting pretty tired of the same old Manwich routine.  This is a great alternative.

text:
This was absolutely delicious.  Instead of using garlic powder, I minced a large clove of garlic and added that in to cook about a minute before I drained the fat off of the meat and veggies.  I also did not have enough ketchup.. only a half cup.. so I substituted the last 1/4 cup with a good squirt (probably about 2oz) of tomato paste and a splash of water.  I think it gave it a deeper flavor.  This recipe will be used over and over in my house!

text:
This is not a great sloppy joe recipe, but it does the job it is supposed to do.  It's simple with very few ingredients and tastes like sloppy joes out of the can would.  The ketchup is the main flavor, and in the end retains a lot of that flavor.  If you want the DELICIOUS sloppy joe recipe that your mother made, this isn't it.  If you want something simple and easy, that is healthier than the canned stuff, this is for you.

text:
My #1 Sloppy Joe recipe I go to.  Been making this recipe most of my life. Sometimes I leave out the green pepper because of those that don't like it but I love it in the recipe. This is just a basic home cooking comfort food. I cook large recipes of this and then freeze it in smaller containers to heat up or use in other casserole recipes. Works great.UPDATE:  I just served sloppy joes to our church for Lenten service dinner. I adjusted the recipe for 120 and that took two 10# rolls of burger to make. We left out the green peppers and cut the brown sugar to half and used 1/2 cup of dried onions instead of fresh. Easy. We served 150 servings with that and received rave reviews.

Thank you, Tamara, for this submission!

I agree with others; this is a very good basic starting receipe.  If you do not like the taste of green pepper as it can be a little bitter, add red pepper.  I would not leave out due to the health benefits of the pepper.  I like to adjust the receipes to make them as healthy as possible.  This is so easy to adjust to your individual preferences, less sugar, more heat, more sloppy, etc. As for Ozzychef.  You obviously do not know anything about Sloppy Joes so do not comment on something you know nothing about.

This was absolutely delicious. I had to rate it. We are actually on a vegan diet during lent and also other times of the year. Instead of the beef, we used portabella mushrooms & I only had spicy brown mustard so I used that. Very simple sauce and your recipe was written perfectly, those were the only things I did differently. So, you can also post a vegan-friendly Sloppy Joe recipe. I thank you for a comforting sauce recipe. We didnt have rolls on hand & it's way to cold to go to the store just for that. We did have pillsbury crescent roll dough. I used one can & lined it into a square pan like a pie crust, if you will; slapped on the sloppy joe and then used another one on top. Pretty good. Thats how I cheat and make a pot pie/casserole in a hurry.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these for the family for the first time, and they loved them ! I just made a couple of tweaks, though. I used 1/4 cup BBQ sauce + 1/2 cup ketchup, and to avoid soggy hamburger buns, I toasted the insides of the buns under the broiler until lightly browned. Load the bottom halves with the meat, top with some sauteed mushroom slices if desired, then some shredded mozza cheese, and put just the bottom halves back under the broiler for 1-2 minutes until the mozza melts. Cover with the upper bun halves, and serve. Delicious !

text:
These were good and my kids loved them!  My kids, especially my son doesn't like spicy, and these aren't spicy at all. Very sweet, if you like the sweet kind of sloppy joes.  As someone said, the recipe doesn't make a whole lot, so if you are making a bunch of sloppy joes, double or even triple the recipe.  Also, if you would like them a little more "saucier", you can add a little water and it thickens up nicely, but keeps a nice sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this because my hubby was craving a sloppy joe.  Neither of us had eaten one since we were kids so we didn't know what to expect. It was really good!  I did make a few changes: like others I used 2 cloves of garlic instead of powder.  I also added 3 T. Worcestershire and 1 T. cider vinegar. While it was simmering I decided it needed more liquid so I added some water and more ketchup. To make it more appealing to my kids I took a suggestion from another website and put the mixture on two crescent roll triangles, added cheese, then put two more crescent roll triangles on top, sealed them together and baked it at 375 for 10 minutes.  Yum!

None
text:
I love this recipe, and so does my 19 month old and my hubby!!! It is so easy and tastes great. After reading other reviews, I was worried about it being too sweet so I did a small heaping 1/4 C. of green pepper and a heaping teaspoon of mustard instead of leveling them, and it turned out just right.  Also, I think that the sauce would've burned if I simmered it for 30 min. because it barely coated the meat. So, I added some water and let that simmer down, and that worked wonderfully. Thanks so much, I was looking for a good sloppy joe recipe for over a year and I finally found it!!!

text:
Yummy!  Made these for father's day and everyone loved it!  I did however deviated from the recipe.  I doubled the recipe, and tripled the sauce.  Used real garlic and red bell pepper.  I left out the brown sugar, used 1 1/2 cups of ketchup and 1/2 of bbq sauce (honey garlic).  I didn't have mustard powder, so I just added a tblsp of mustard and a few dashes of worschetire sauce and added one tomato, diced.  Turned out perfect, not too sweet and not too much bbq flavor, all flavors balanced out nicely.  Served this with fries on the side, everyone said this was a keeper!  Thanks

This was my mom’s recipe too.  I don’t use bell pepper because hubby doesn’t like it.  I use this same recipe for sloppy joe pie.  Super easy for a bit of a change.  I buy refrigerated boxed pie crust, bake bottom crust 5 minutes or so on 450 so it is baked throughout, then fill with mix, sprinkle grated cheese, cover with top crust and bake 15 minutes or so until golden brown.  Tx for a great recipe!

Tried it tonight, changed it a little. I used 1 1/2tsp. Minced garlic,1 1/2c. ketchup, 1 1/2  Tblsp. Mustard, 6 Tblsp. Brn  sugar for sauce, & since I only use extra lean hamburger , there was no liquid to drain. With the onions & green pepper, I used  2/3 of each. My husband was ecstatic, he said it was The Best sloppy joes he'd ever eaten. I know he meant it, coz he is a food freak & if he hadn't liked it, he would NOT have eaten it. He would have hit a junk fast food instead. He actually ate 3. We will definitely be having this on a reg. basis. Thank you for the excellent recipe Tamara.

country:
None
text:
We use this recipe exclusively and love it. I Do add a dash of chili powder, and 1/3 cup of dry oats (helps it stick together well), and we always serve Brickhouse slaw on top. (2 cups shredded cabbage,1/4 c. diced onion, 1 shredded carrot, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/8 tsp black pepper, 2/3 cup real mayonnaise)--my husband was NEVER a slaw fan but now refuses to have his Joes served any other way!!) Excellent recipe!

text:
This is our fave recipe for sloppy joes. I like my joes more soupy so I add a 14 oz can of diced tomatoes. I swipe out the green pepper for 2 cups of diced celery. I also add a tablespoon of white balsamic vinegar. It adds another level of flavor but it  does not taste vinegary at all.  I do this to cut the sweet flavor of the  brown sugar. I brown hamburger buns in butter. Yummy

I made this recipe tonight, using the prescribed pound of hamburger, and more than doubling the amounts of onion & green pepper. I also used minced garlic instead of powder. It was a hit with my old sidekick here, who likes foods sweet. I wasn't quite so impressed, so next time I may use molasses instead of the brown sugar. I also added a sprinkle of ground red pepper to offset the sweetness. But overall, I would judge it a very good recipe and will be making it more often, if only to stay on the good side of this husband with the gargantuan sweet tooth!

Only addition I made was 1.5 teaspoon worcestershire sauce.  I almost minced the onions and peppers so you didn't even know they were there when eating. Easy to make, even the future chefs can help.  We will add to the rotation and never use Manwich again!

text:
The first time I made this recipe I followed it exact, so the five star rating is for the original. That being said, I make these all the time and do a few things differently to simplify things. I use a whole onion and a whole green pepper for 3 reasons: no measuring, added nutrition, and it stretches the 1lb of meat a little further. I use more garlic pwd., less sugar, and sometimes djion mustard. These are definitly a family favorite!

text:
UPDATE: I CAN'T BELIEVE I EVER ALTERED THIS RECIPE. THIS IS PERFECT AS WRITTEN. I STRONGLY URGE YOU TO TRY THIS AS LEAST ONCE, AS IS. THIS WILL NOW BE MY GO-TO (HOMEMADE) SLOPPY JOE RECIPE. I WILL STILL HANG ONTO MY SHORTCUT RECIPE (MY TOH VERSION CALLS FOR A HANDFUL OF CONVENIENCE INGREDIENTS), BUT THIS WILL BE THE ONE I TURN TO WHEN I CRAVE THE "REAL" DEAL. Although I prefer my go-to sloppy Joe recipe a *tad* better, I enjoyed deviating from the "same old, same old." And although fine as is, I made a few changes (I know!). As wifeyluvs2cook did, I too added a T of (Bull's-Eye Original) BBQ sauce, a couple shakes of Worcestershire sauce and a pinch of cayenne pepper. Because my BBQ sauce was pretty sweet, I HALVED the amount of brown sugar called for. None of these changes were necessary, but I can't seem to try a new recipe without making it my own lol! :) Serving our "Joes" with potato chips and dill pickle spears made for a quick, fuss-free meal! Thanks for sharing your recipe, Tamara. :-)

This is an excellent basic recipe for Sloppy Joes that is far more creative than opening up a can of Manwich. I made a few minor changes such as adding crushed red pepper and tobasco sauce. I also added extra garlic powder (1/2 tsp) and additional ketchup and brown sugar because I like my meat on the sweet side. Oh, and speaking of the meat, I used extra lean ground turkey. My bf loved them, and they even tasted good cold. Will make again, and next time might add jalapeno and cayenne for extra heat. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
So good! My fiance loathes manwich (more than most people would expect) so I haven't eaten a sloppy joe in forever. This passed his test by far! I used red pepper insetad of green, and that was the only change in ingredient. I used a little more meat but tried hard not to up the ketchup more than necessary - that stuff is full of more sugar than people realize. It did turn out nice and thick, and was GREAT as leftovers, no surprise! Not a crumb was wasted. Will make again the next time I have ground beef and don't feel like doing anything too fancy. (This is also good on bread, like that 45 calorie a slice bread... just saying.)

text:
4 stars as written, but easy to turn into 5 stars!

Original recipe needs more sauce.

To turn it into 5 stars, use an entire small onion and bell pepper.  Double the sauce ingredients and sub up to 1/2 cup of the ketchup (1.5 cups total) with bbq sauce.  Adjust brown sugar depending on how sweet your bbq sauce is.  We used a honey chipotle to add a bit of heat.

text:
Easy to make; converted recipe to use 1 & 3/4 lb of ground beef (10 servings) While meat, onions and green peppers were browning, I combined other ingredients in a 2 cup glass measuring cup.  I was careful not to over brown the meat and veggies and stirred the sloppy joes frequently during the 30 minutes. My husband said these were the best sloppy joes he ever had in his life! Not too sloppy, not dry, a little sweet and great tasting. We had only enough for leftovers for 1 meal: next time will increase servings so we have more leftovers.

text:
This is the best sloppy joes recipe in the world.  When I saw it I was taken back to my grade school days and my favorite school lunch.  I followed the recipe for the most part but made it my own by adding 1/4 cup small diced carrot with the onion, pepper and beef.  After draining I added 1/4 cup mild Rotel, 1/8 cup sweet chipotle bbq sauce and 1 tsp. liquid smoke to the other ingredients and used less ketchup.  The result was a robust, delicious sloppy that made my mouth sing.  Thanks for posting Tamara.

text:
Really great base to get started on making homemade sloppy joes that allow me to control the ingredients and improve the nutritional value for my family. I've found that the boys don't seem to notice when I add  1/2 bag of fajita blend frozen veggies (onions and mixed bell peppers), which really ups the veggie serving without causing a dinnertime crisis. Also found that using about 1/2 cup of chili sauce to replace some of the ketchup gives this recipe a richer flavor. Many thanks for the idea to add a touch of vinegar; we use apple cider to keep a little hint of sweetness.

text:
We normally don't like sloppy joes but I made this for friends who got together to help us put a swing set together.  Everyone like it a lot including my hubby who doesn't like sloppy joes too much because it's too sweet.  I made it with organic ketchup which has less sugar than the normal ketchup.  If I were to make this with normal ketchup, I would reduce the amount of brown sugar even more so it's not so sweet.  Also, I used very good quality garlic powder (makes a huge difference).  A keeper!

text:
I agree with the other reviewers that said that it is too sweet and too dry.  With the ketchup and the brown sugar it was overkill on sugar for my taste.  You can definitely taste the ketchup in there. I love ketchup but I felt it was overpowering.  As for the dry, there was barely enough sauce to cover all the meat.  We prefer it more "sloppy," I guess you can say.  I think I'm going to look for another recipe for sloppy joes.  Maybe one with a tomato sauce base instead of ketchup will better suit our tastes.

text:
These were Yummy and kid approved! My kids kept raving over them. I added 1/4 c  of BBQ sauce as suggested by others, 1 T Worcestershire, 1 t garlic powder, and I also added a little  water because mine were a little too thick. I did not add the brown sugar, they were sweet enough with all the ketchup and BBQ. I made them in the morning before work, and my dh just had to reheat. A little cole slaw & frozen fries and dinner was ready in no time! This will be my Sloppy Joe go to recipe!

text:
I will NEVER use canned crud again!!!  I've made this twice now.. once exactly as written w/ground beef, and it was  huge huge hit! my picky 5yr old raved.. and ate an entire sandwhich! that's HUGE for her!!    the second time I made it, I used the sauce recipe as is(except doubled the recipe), and put it over shredded cooked turkey breast meat that I had leftover. Put the sauce, the turkey meat and some diced onions in a crock pot, mixed it all up well, and set to low until it just started to bubble.  Turned it to warm until I was ready to serve.  Again.. a huge huge hit!!!    This will be put into regular rotation in my house now.. be it w/ground beef as tradtional sloppy joes, or shredded beef, pork, chicken or turkey as a sort of pulled meat bbq sandwhich.  YUM!!

This was a good recipe, but a little on the dry side for me- I had to nearly double to sauce to get a traditional “sloppy” texture.  The flavors are excellent and the taste is very much that of a classic sloppy joe.  I would only suggest doubling the sauce- other than that I wouldn’t change a thing.

text:
I just started volunteering at a recovery home for alcohlics and addicts, making them dinner a couple times a month. I'm in college, so I have a tight budget. I needed something that wasn't too expensive, but would feed a lot of hungry men... I tell ya, this was a hit! I was so worried about everything turning out okay, and I was MORE than pleased with this recipe. I tripled the recipe and used ground turkey instead of ground beef because it's cheaper and has less fat and calories and tastes about the same as ground beef. I think I let it simmer a little too long because they weren't as juicy as I'd hoped, but they were still awesome sloppy joes! I'll definitely remember this one for big parties! Kudos to the creator!

text:
I only gave this 3 stars because it did require some "doctoring".  I browned the beef with 1/2 chopped onion and one minced garlic.  Then added the rest of the ingredients as listed, ecept using only 1 tsp brown sugar.  I had to increase the ketchup to about 1 cup, increase the mustard by about another tsp. and add some water.  The flavor still wasn't quite right so I added 1/2 tsp Italian seasoning, 1 tbl barbeque sauce and some hot pepper flakes.  It ended up being pretty tasty - my husband couldn't tell that it wasn't the canned stuff ( I don't know if that's good or bad!)

text:
This is so similar to the recipe my mom always used and gave to me many, many years ago.In Pennsylvania we call it Bar-B-Q. People in other parts of the country are always confused when I say this is Bar-B-Q. I don't measure my ingredients but use the taste test. I always make it a bit on the sweet side and everyone loves it. I use white sugar only. I am celiac...on a gluten free diet and this is perfect because Manwich is not on the acceptable list for me. This is 100 X better than Manwich. It's worth the extra time. I use the crock pot, too, after I brown the hamburger. In fact, next wk/end we are having a wine tasting party and when a friend heard I was having Sloppy Joe's she said they would come because of that as they are THE BEST! Try it with white sugar, and make it a bit sweet. Great with homemade coleslaw!!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I never liked sloppy joes growing up so I was hesitant to make this, but am glad I did! I've been making this recipe for almost 2 years, and it'll be the only one I use. I add about 1/4 cup BBQ sauce, and a little water for more sauce.  If I need to get rid of celery, I add it, but not too much otherwise it's overpowering.  I'll also add whatever kind of bell pepper I have on hand--doesn't have to be green. I usually double the recipe then freeze ice cream scoop piles on parchment paper, and after frozen store in a plastic bag.  This works great for quick meals.  Simply take a couple balls out, put in a bowl, and heat in the microwave.

text:
Loved this recipe! I omitted the green bell pepper and substituted 1/2 cup minced celery.  Used the food processor to mince the onion and celery and minced 1 piece fresh garlic also thus omitting the garlic powder. I added the minced mixture to the beef just before the beef completely browned.  Once beef was browned then I added the other ingredients.  I use to use a powdered mix and will never again.  This recipe is great!

text:
Best Sloppy Joe recipe I've found.  I took a tip from "Manwich" and added chili powder and oregano to cut the sweetness - I think it works better than vinegar, plus the flavor it imparts is more authentic.  I also added a bit more mustard powder and a dash of Worcestershire sauce.  I think next time I might add a little tomato paste and water to make more sauce and a small clove of fresh grated garlic.

text:
I live in Australia, where most people have never heard of sloppy joes except for when we see them on movies (Billy Madison for my family!) - My brothers have been bugging me to make these since they saw that movie years ago. I never thought i could sit through a meal with what looked like soggy mince with ketchup and a bread roll. I was so wrong! I finally gave in and instead of me making them, i got my 15 year old brother to experiment while i was on my way home. I have never seen something gobbled up so quickly... not ever! They were really yummy and sweet, which from the reviews is what they are supposed to be like, and he made it exactly as the recipe states. Thanks for the great recipe that we will use again and again. (The only thing i would change is maybe not use the green pepper - we diced it up in the mixmaster and all night all i could smell was green pepper! - so maybe use 2 sweet onions instead)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, this rocked! First time I've ever made homemade joe's and I won't use canned ever again. I did use 1.5 lbs. ground beef, did 3/4 cup bbq sauce and 3/4 cup ketchup. Added 2 tsp. of cider vinegar, and some chili powder. I used dry onion flakes and garlic powder (I don't like chunks in my joes). Chopped up a bit of green pepper very small. Did not add mustard. After simmering for 30 minutes in the skillet, I put it in the crockpot on low/keep warm for a few hours. YUM! Hubby loved it too! Thanks!

text:
Much better than Manwich! Followed reviews and used 1/2 cup ketchup & 1/4 cup BBQ sauce.  Also added some Worcestershire sauce.  It is important to let the Joes simmer so that the flavors blend.  Next time I make them I will follow a review that used ketchup & chili sauce.  I think the chili sauce will add a nice kick.  I suggest doubling this recipe if serving 3 or more.  I don't see any possible way that this recipe could make 6 servings.  Overall, a good recipe & I will make again.

text:
I just made this for the first time in my life today, always added either the canned version or with the powder in the envelope.  That's what I grew up on, as a baby boomer.  THIS IS NOT MY MA'S SLOPPY JOE!!!!!!!!  It's ridiculously better!  It is just plain old tasty, delicious, and easy to make.  I made 6 times more than this, and it was enough for probably 15-20 people.  I tasted when done, and it was a little TOO sweet, so I added two small cans of tomato paste with the same amount of water to tone it down.  Also reduced ketchup by 1/2 cup so I could add 1/2 cup barbecue sauce, and was glad I did.  I also added a couple pinches of red pepper flakes.  This one's going down as a family favorite,  My thanks to you for the recipe!

Love these sloppy joes - one of the best comfort dishes ever for me, and this is the only recipe I use for them!!  I use less brown sugar, a tad more mustard and then throw in a few shots of worcestershire sauce along with real garlic as opposed to the powder.  I also add some water or broth before I let it simmer, or it tends to stick to the skillet. Using ground turkey doesn't change the taste of these either!! Thanks!

text:
It feels a little strange to give a sloppy joe recipe 5 stars, as they just don't strike me as 5 star food in most cases, but for sloppy joes, these were very good!  My husband and 6 year old practically inhaled them.  They weren't as well received by my four year old, but nothing with meat ever is.  I used ground turkey instead of beef (on sale for $1.99 per pound!).  I used 1/2 cup kethup and 1/4 cup of spicy BBQ sauce.  I added a shredded carrot and a little more green pepper than called for since I'm always trying to sneak in some extra vegetables.  I served these with french fries and veggies with dip and it was a quick, easy, inexpensive meal.

text:
WOW!!  I get to have sloppy joes again! lol My husband HATES anything sloppy to eat so for the past 20+ years they were never on the menu.  I made this recipe, hollowed out some Bolillo rolls (both sides - the bottom is just about a 1/2 deep), placed cheddar cheese in the bottom, filled the top with this mixture and no more "Sloppy" Joe!! Also, my daughter who HATES onions and green peppers, LOVED it. Pleased all of the picky eaters in this house!! I have made this 3 times since first getting the recipe 2 weeks ago, requested by my husband!!  Once I did make a change of using brown sugar b-b-que sauce instead of the ketchup and brown suger.....was really good and kind of stick to using that instead now.  Highly recommended from this house.

text:
I haven't had sloppy joes for years and this is how I remember them!  Great basic recipe but with a few modifications- decrease brown sugar to 2 Tsp and ketchup to 1/3 cup, add 2-3 cloves finely chopped garlic, season to taste with chili powder, paprika, and onion powder. And for a little extra kick add 2 Tbls of BBQ Sauce. I made them extra sloppy by adding 1 cup of tomato sauce.  Thanks for a great recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy sloppy joe recipe!  I did, however, make some changes to accomadate what I had on hand and how we like it.  I was making this for a pot luck so I used, 3 1/2 lbs. ground beef, 1 cup each green pepper and onion (about one small pepper and one med. onion).  When browning the beef, I seasoned with salt/pepper/chili powder.  In a bowl, I mixed 1 can (12 oz) tomato paste, 1 can (15 oz) tomato sauce, 1/4 cup brown sugar, 3 tsp. mustard, 3/4 tsp. garlic powder, and a few drops hot sauce.  After browning and draining meat, I added this sauce and simmered in my crock pot, adding a little water to keep from getting too dry.  Very good, and it was eaten up quickly!

text:
This was a great recipe, but I did make a few changes. Instead of the chopped onion and garlic powder, I mixed an envelope of onion soup mix to the ground beef, and added 1/2 teaspoon minced garlic while it browned. I used dijon mustard and a full cup of ketchup, added a tablespoon of Worstershire, and only used one tablespoon of brown sugar. I didn't add any salt since the soup mix had plenty. With toasted buns, it was absolutely delicious. My 4-year-old gobbled it right up, and she asked for seconds! This was very tasty and easy to make, and I will use this method to make Sloppy Joes from now on. Thanks, Tamara!

None
country:
None
text:
YUM.  Doubled the recipe, making it the perfect  Potluck dish.  SO easy to make (Perfect for college students on the go who already have all the simple ingredients!)  I did have to keep adding WATER after I mixed in the ketchup (maybe 3/4 cup or so?) so that it could actually "simmer", careful not to thin it down too much.  It held up beautifully.  I found using a ground beef (+25% fat, most of it drained out anyway, plus the beef was MUCH cheaper than the chuck, so bought 2.5 lbs instead of 2.0 to compensate) instead of a ground chuck made my sloppy joes a lot more homogenous and appealing to the eye.  I seasoned and browned the meat first, then let the beef drain in a collander, leaving a little fat in the pot to caramelize the onions and bellpeppers (also seasoned) for a couple minutes, then tossed the beef back in and simmered for 30.  I added more mustard to counteract the sweetness.  Nexttime, I will add less sugar and more bellpeppers.  Thanks!!

Very good, I did add and sub. some items from the recipe (like always...hehe).  I did not add the mustard or the brown sugar.  I did how-ever keep the ketchup, onions, and green peppers. BBQ)till it gave it just the right zing of BBQ flavor to it and like most sauces it has amounts of brown sugar to it already so it had the right sweetness to it and no need for the brown sugar.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I simmered the cooked ground beef in a 1/2 cup of chicken broth, garlic powder, a small amount (1/2 tsp?) of onion powder instead of chopped onion, dried green pepper (1 TBS?)  instead of chopped green pepper, a spoon of olive oil, and a I few crushed red pepper flakes (1/4 tsp?), covered, until it reduced to barely wet, to get it extra flavorful. Then I stirred in the ketchup, mustard, and brown sugar and let it simmer, covered, another 5 minutes. 
If it seems too flat at the end, try stirring in a little salt. If it seems too sweet try stirring in a spoon of fresh squeezed lemon or a spoon of vinegar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good Sloppy Joes recipe. Of course I made a few changes. I had more people to feed so I used 1.5 pounds of ground  beef. I doubled everything else except for the brown sugar (I used the 1 tbsp it called for) and added some onion powder and a dash of cumin. 
I browned the veggies on high for about 10 minutes (stirring frequently). I then set them aside and threw in the ground beef, spreading it out all over the surface. I allowed it to brown on high for about 13 minutes before even touching it. This got a nice sear on the beef which added to the flavor. Only then did I separate it and mix in the other ingredients. Turned out perfect!

text:
I just made this recipe and I loved it.  Before making any recipe on the site, I read multiple reviews to look for tips/modifications for the recipe.  In the case of this recipe, I decided make a few of changes.  1) I made 1 1/2 recipe of the sauce ingredients,   2) used 1/2 tomato sauce and 1/2 ketchup and 3) used less brown sugar.  I mixed all of the sauce ingredients together before adding to the ground beef, onion and pepper mixture.  For the sauce I used: 5 ounces tomato sauce, 4 ounces ketchup, 3 tsp brown sugar and 2 tsp mustard.  It was the perfect amount to keep the mixture from becoming too dry after 30-35 minutes of simmering.   Never need to use the canned stuff again.

text:
Versatile! We'd never had sloppy joes before (we're Australian) but the kids and I decided to have  an American themed dinner of Sloppy Joes, complete with crisps on the side. I had read reviews first, so I added the brown sugar last and to taste (used less than half the suggested amount) and I added a bit more mustard, and replaced 1/3 of the tomato sauce/ketchup with bbq sauce. They were yum!

I had made a double-batch, so for tonight's dinner I heated the leftover sloppy joe meat up with a tin of crushed tomatoes and a large handful of frozen peas, corn and carrots. Topped it with some mashed potato and a sprinkling of cheese, and cooked it in the oven as a shepherd's pie. I also turned the day-old leftover buns into garlic bread to serve on the side. This was even more enjoyable than the sloppy joes had been. 

For less than $15 to feed four people two different meals over two nights, we'll be doing this more often. Thanks.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5766721.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did the following modification: used 1/4 cup barbecue and 1/2 ketchup and also, this recipe NEEDS 2 cups of water or broth to simmer in. This sets in the flavor into the beef and makes the meat tender, and with draining the meat juices and putting sauces with not enough liquid into it, it did not have enough liquid to simmer (this may be why people are having problems with it sticking or not cooking properly), just puffed out hot air every few minutes. I also sauteed the onions in butter and balsamic vinegar, then added the beef to it and browned that, drained, then went on with the sauce with water. I've found that sauteing with balsamic is a wonderful compliment to any recipe using tomatoes or tomato sauces (it has a unique sweet tang that compliments the tomato's sweet tang. Don't let the strong vinegar odor fool you, it cooks off, just use about a tablespoon or two and you're good. It's also very good for you, is a very good source of potassium and has other health benefits).

region:

country:
None
text:
I had to make some slight variations due to cooking for those with really strict sugar intake limitations, so replaced the 3TBSP of brown sugar with half that amount of white sugar mixed with low sugar molasses. To fix the flavour loss, 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1tsp of both nutmeg and ground cloves worked nicely, still tasting clearly like classic sloppy joes, with a hint of extra class, and just as easy to make. The base recipe was quick and easy on its own and simple to adjust to my needs without falling apart. Most certainly will fall back on this again in the future!

I didn't add the green peppers just because I'm not a fan but other than that I didn't change a thing and it was delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We're on a health kick, so we used ground turkey. I omitted the bell pepper because I didn't have one on hand. I also sautéed minced garlic with the onions instead of powdered garlic in the sauce, added a pinch of red pepper flakes, and then I added a tsp of soy sauce with the ketchup to add some depth since we used ground turkey. I also added 1/2 cup chicken broth to make it a bit more saucy. Next time, I'll use tomato paste instead of ketchup. It's a great base, and one I'll continue to experiment with!

text:
I made this using Turkey meat. The taste was great, but I did change it a bit. I added about 2 TBSP of Worcestershire to the sauce mix in a bowl and then added it to the meat. I am not sure if anyone else's was like this, but for it to be able to simmer for 30 min, I HAD to add water. I added about 1/2 cup(enough to almost cover all the meat evenly) and brought to a boil. Simmered for about 20 minutes, until the sauce thickened back up. This allows the flavors to cook and saturate the meat, rather than just sit on it.

country:

text:
Let me add a caveat.  I wanted to like this recipe.  I wanted to rave and shout about how wonderful it was.  But, as written, this recipe had one major issue: too sweet. 
I made it as is, and could only taste the brown sugar and the ketchup.  It was too overpowering.  
I then made it a second time, omitting the brown sugar altogether, and using a spicy wholegrain mustard (Zatarains Creole Wholegrain Mustard), upping it to 1 tablespoon.    I also added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce.  The reincarnation we loved.  But as written, it is a one-note wonder that just didn't work for us.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/732405.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Instead of 3/4 cup of ketchup, I used 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce, 1/4 cup of ketchup, plus I added liquid smoke, 2 tablespoons of sofrito, 1 teaspoon of minced garlic, 1 teaspoon of olive oil, 1/3 cup of water, 1 teaspoon of cornstarch. Stir sofrito, garlic, onions and olive oil in a pan. Mix the meat with the rest of ingredients in a bowl (the brown sugar, salt, pepper, mustard, BBQ sauce, ketcup). When everything is well mixed, transfer to the pan with the golden onions, sofrito and garlic. Let it cook for about 30 mins. Warning! If you cook this while any hungry male is in the house, you might be harrassed. Stay strong and take your time. Enjoy.

text:
I used this recipe with a twist...literally. 

I added spicy sausage links. I cooked them fully then chopped them (more like minced them) down in my Nutribullet. Additionally, I used the Nutribullet for both the onion and green pepper (drained the juice). 

Other than those twists, I followed the recipe and this was the best tasting sloppy joe EVER. I have leftovers for the next few days.. yay.

text:
5 stars because the original recipe was great, but even better than that, I used a couple of the reviews edits, and added a twist of my own. I used 1/2 cup ketchup, 1/8 cup BBQ sauce, 1/8 cup Italian dressing (gives amazing flavor mixed with the BBQ sauce), a teaspoon of Worcestershire, and a pinch of steak seasoning. Had an amazing flavor. I also put two pieces of sliced cheese in after it was done cooking, and stirred until completely melted. It was a huge hit!! (:

I told the kids I was going to make sloppy joe n tator tots for dinner and come to find out I didn't have a can of my regular popular brand of sloppy joe sauce which we always use and since we had artic blast with wind chill of minus 15... text:
Made this last night for dinner.  The only change I made was substituting the green bell pepper with a red bell pepper.  Otherwise, made it exactly as written.  It was super!  Both the BF and I loved it and he said it was a keeper.  Next time, I will double the recipe so we have some leftovers for the next day!  UPDATE:  Doubled the recipe using the following changes:  2 lbs beef (depending on the level of lean/fat in the meat, I used up to 20 oz of ketchup for more sauce); 1 lrg red bell pepper; 2 cups chopped sweet onion; 1 t garlic powder; 1 T mustard; and kept the brown sugar at 3T.  It turned out awesome!

text:
This was a big hit at our house.  My husband said, "This is the best sloppy joe I have ever had."  Good enough for me.
I made a few adjustments.  Doubled the recipe but tripled the sauce, left out the bell pepper since we don't care for them, and also added a total of about 1/2 cup of water while it was simmering since it seemed very thick.  I was afraid it would taste like ketchup, but the flavor was perfect by the time it had simmered down.  I butter toasted the buns and added a thin slice of cheddar cheese.  Mmmm!
I also took another reviewer's advice and froze some in muffin tins for future single servings.  Freeze, pop them out, place them in a freezer bag and easy servings to reheat later.  This recipe is a winner!

country:
None
text:
This really is a five star recipe, but it needs a few adjustments. Instead of using the full amount of ketchup I cut out half a cup and replaced it with BBQ sauce. I also added a bit of sage and a tablespoon of apple cider vinegar. I followed the advice of other reviewers and doubled the entire liquid mixture, but it did turn out a little watery so I ended up needing to add 4 tablespoons of flour. Next time I try it on the stove top I don't think I'll double it again, but I do plan on using this recipe in the slow cooker so for that I'll double it again to keep it moist. This is a perfect base recipe, but taste it as you go and add/exchange ingredients to get it perfect for you and your family's tastes.

text:
This recipe was too sweet for my taste. I feel like it could have done without the brown sugar, since the ketchup has sugar in it anyway. I added some chili powder and paprika to balance the sweetness, which ended up tasting like a really great BBQ sauce. Not my favorite for sloppy joes, but the hubby told me to write it down as a BBQ sauce recipe! I think next time I will leave out the brown sugar and maybe try tomato sauce or stewed tomatoes instead of ketchup. All in all, it wasn't bad, but I'd rather have the canned stuff than this recipe.

text:
The first time I made this, I made it exactly as the recipe stated.  My husband said they were the best sloppy joes he'd ever had.  I made them again tonight but was missing a couple ingredients so I was a little nervous that they wouldn't be as good.  I substituted jarred roasted red peppers for the green pepper and minced garlic(2tsp) and garlic salt(1/2tsp) for the garlic powder.  In addition, we love onions so I used about 3/4 cup.  My husband told me I had to write it down because these were now the best.

This is a great recipe, but if you have them, try the roasted red bell peppers in the jar.  We loved it.

text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious! After reading the comments, I tweaked it a little by replacing about 1/4 cup of the ketchup with BBQ sauce (any BBQ sauce will work, I used Kraft Honey bbq sauce since it's my fave), omitting the brown sugar to avoid it being oversweet, and adding a little more yellow mustard. Perfect on warm hamburger buns. Served it with a vinegar-based coleslaw (store baught coleslaw bag, apple cider vinegar, sugar, and a squeeze of ketchup) that went perfectly with the sloppy joes. This meal was incredibly fast and easy to make. Better, healthier, cheaper, and easier than the canned manwich. A++++!

text:
Rating this a 3 as is. My changes:  used 1.25 lbs. lean ground beef, doubled the onion and pepper, red pepper instead of green, 3 cloves fresh garlic chopped, doubled the mustard and used 1/2 Dijon and 1/2 yellow mustard, 3/4 C. ketchup, 3/4 C. BB@ sauce, 4 Tblsps. worsteshire sauce, no salt or black pepper. I did not drain and added approximately 1/2-3/4 C. water as it was cooking to get it to the best consistency. Served open-faced on rolls...yummy!
Basic recipe you can build on.

text:
Tasty and simple using ingredients on hand.  My family loved it.  I have been doing something different with my ground hamburger and it tastes much better.  Instead of adding the chopped onion with the raw hamburger - I add the chopped onion after I drain the hamburger - then I cook them both together for a few more minutes.  The onion keeps it's flavor and makes everything you use ground beef and onion mixtures taste much better.  My husband even notices and he isn't crazy about onions like the rest of us are.

text:
This is a great basic recipe. I never follow a recipe, down to the details, but rather let it 'inspire me'. My inspiration from this one included using pork sausage, dehydrated chopped onion and green bell peppers, fresh minced garlic, regular mustard, raw sugar, tomato sauce, a few hot pepper sprinkles, some paprika powder, and a few shakes of Worcestershire sauce. I let it cook down until nice and thick. Then we used it in tortillas rolled up as burritos. Family approved!

text:
In addition to the ingredients for this recipe - You need to add 1 - 1 1/2 cups of water, bring to a boil and then let simmer for 40 minutes - add a dash of Worcestershire and this is the perfect dish!  It will thicken once removed from the heat in about 5 minutes.  It was not too "ketchupy" or "sugary" once you add the water.  It had a nice smooth taste.  We always use ground turkey and the kids don't even know it!!  (to get away from the "pink slime" in most ground beef)

So quick, easy and yummy. I substituted ground turkey for the beef and added veggies like 1 cup diced carrots, 2 diced roma tomato and 1 can kidney beans while cooking the meat. It needed a little extra sauce with all the extras I put in. I added some bbq sauce that I needed to get rid of.  Piled it over whole wheat toast. Yum! Not sure its even sloppy Joes anymore with all that I changed, but its a easy weeknight meal.

As many others have said, this is a really good basic sloppy joe recipe.  I did as other suggested and doubled everything but the meat.  I also cooked the meat and veggies on the stove and then transferred them to the crock pot and added the sauce and cooked on low for about 2-3 hours.  I used dijon mustard, I used red and green bell pepper,  and I added a few dashes of tobasco.  It was really delicious!  And definitely an easy meal to feed a crowd!

My boyfriend said "wow, honey, I've never had sloppy joes with flavor before!"
That speaks for itself! I added extra ketchup, BBQ sauce, horseradish mustard, a beef bouillon cube, 3 cloves minced garlic, and thickened with a little cornstarch. I left out bell pepper. Otherwise followed exactly as stated. Couldn't even tell it was 93/7 ground beef!

text:
This recipe doesn't need another review but I just had to put my two bits in. This was fantastic. I usually use the packaged seasoning for sloppy joes but didn't have any on hand and I was really craving these for dinner. Let me just say, packaged seasoning is no longer allowed in my house! This was so easy and it calls for ingredients that I usually have on hand. I was a little worried at first because when I added the sauce to the hamburger it was really sweet but after simmering for the 30 minutes all the flavors came together perfectly. This is the only sloppy Joe recipe I will use from now on.

A very good, quick, and easy meal!  I spooned the meat mixture on toasted hamburger buns.  My husband added mayo, cheddar, and pepperjack cheese to his and said it was awesome.  I'll probably stick to just the toasted bun myself, but as long as everyone's satisfied, this is a keeper!  By the way, it is extremely important to note that for the nine years we've been married he has been adamantly against having sloppy joes.  Period.  It's a pleasant surprise that he loved these as I've always loved sloppy joes.  My toddler son loved them too.

text:
I changed the recipe around a bit. Instead of peppers and onions (we don't like either), I added 1/2 tsp of onion powder. I also left out the mustard. I used the 3/4 cup of ketchup, but also added 1/4 cup of BBQ sauce. I only used 2 tsp of brown sugar since the BBQ sweetens the meat already. I always brown the meat and add everything to the crock pot to slow cook for an hour or 2. I also add 1/4 cup of water to keep everything moist.

text:
Only one complaint- not enough leftovers!  This is a great basic recipe that you can tweak to your liking.  I looked at others' reviews and substituted 1/4 cup of BBQ sauce for 1/4 of the ketchup.  I reduced the brown sugar to 2 teaspoons, but probably could have used only 1 teaspoon or left it out all together because the sauce is pretty sweet (but I like sweet).  If you like this recipe, check out Elaine's Sweet and Tangy BBQ Beef, as the sauce is very similar.  Very good, and worth the little bit of effort it takes to use instead of buying canned mix.

country:

text:
The best part was the brown sugar.  I prepared this in a frying pan with the intention of transferring it to the crock pot for serving later.  I found the original to be way too dry for that and added a whole cup of water! I also did not use the green pepper as my digestive tract  just doesn't handle that well.
This recipe closely resembles one I've been making for about 50 years and which my family raves about.  Instead of mustard it calls for Worcestershire Sauce.  It also has about a half tsp of oregano in it.  I usually stir in a tablespoon of flour after browning the meat and onions, which gives it a nice consistency--sloppy, but not overly so.

Save this to your recipe box, it is a keeper. I defrosted 1lb of lean ground beef slated for burgers a little too much and boy am I glad I did. I stayed close to the original recipe except I only had spicy brown mustard. I also added a little onion powder, worch sauce and a sprinkle of Goya Total Seasoning (I use this in about everything!) My family loved it. Thanks Tamara!

text:
Excellent recipe...I added a few different ingredients and my grandkids wolfed it down...I cut the ketchup back to 1/2 cup and added 1/4 cup of barbecue sauce..I left out the brown sugar because it was an ingredient in my barbecue sauce..After it was all combined I added a small can of diced tomatoes and about 1 teaspoon of Italian seasoning...Put a cover on it and let it simmer for close to an hour...It was very simple but very good....I served it on hamburger buns,topped it with some salad greens and put a small amount of mayo on the top bun...real success

userID:

Display Name:
RyanMurphy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The great thing about this recipe is that it makes use of things you always have in the kitchen so its great for a quick meal. My one complaint is the sweetness. It really kind of ruined this for me. After simmering and tasting I was amazed it was still so sugary because of the ketchup. To make up for sweetness I added about a tablespoon more mustard, a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce, some red pepper flakes, about a teaspoon of chili powder and some ground red pepper. That helped. Next time I would cut the ketchup to 1/3 of a cup and cut the sweetness with a little vinegar. Add one teaspoon of brown sugar or omit completely. I would also consider adding tomato paste to add some acidity but still keeping that tomato flavor.

text:
I made a zillion changes, but wanted to say this is a fantastic basic recipe.  Get creative!!  I used ground turkey, shallot and red bell pepper in place of the beef, onion and green pepper.  I also left out the salt (tons of that in the ketchup), but added a splash of red wine vinegar and Worcestershire sauce.  As it was cooking down, it started to dry out, so I added a tablespoon of water to keep in the moisture.  This is a delicious recipe and I highly recommend it either as it stands or for getting creative!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe will insure you never use packet or canned sloppy joe mix, again!  I always used packet mixes for my sloppy joes because of the ease of use.  Until I found this super simple, no-fail recipe!  You can't screw it up!  And you can add and subtract whatever suits your taste with whatever you happen to have on hand.  I was out of ketchup, so substituted one can of tomato paste and a little water tonight.  Turned out excellent.  The first time I made it, I actually added 1/2 packet of spagetti sauce seasoning, because I didn't have any garlic powder.  Turned out excellent.  I love the consistency of this recipe, and I love that I can omit the green peppers and onions and still have a tasty meal.  These are the sloppy joes I remember as a kid!  Excellent basic recipe you can play with if you don't have exactly the right ingredients.  Thanks for sharing this one!!

I haven't made Sloppy Joes prior to trying this recipe but I remember them back in school. They were so awful that I hesitated to try this. I use mustard powder rather than prepared mustard. I exclude the salt and brown sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe! I'm rating the recipe as written, but a few simple changes bump it up to 5 stars. I was cooking for 2, so I used half a pound of ground beef, but I adjusted the proportions of everything else. So, for half a pound of lean ground beef, I used 1/2 cup chopped onion and 1/2 cup green pepper (we like veggies here), 1/2 tsp ground garlic, 1 1/2 tsp spicy brown mustard, and 1/2 cup ketchup. The ketchup added enough sweetness, so there was no need for additional sugar. It turned out zippy and tasty.

text:
I never made homemade sloppy joes before.  It is pretty easy and affordable to make.  I found I like it better as it is not as sweet as the jar or packet products from the store. I used 93 percent lean ground beef, so no draining was necessary.  Might need to double recipe to make a decent amount, as some grown men can eat a couple or more, and it reheats well the next day. When I made it I served with chips.  Good quick, easy, cheap meal.

None
text:
All in all my family and I were not fans. Between the ketchup and the brown sugar, it was just too sweet! It felt like I was eating some sort of meaty dessert. We do plan on giving it another try substituting tomato paste and half a can (measured from the tomato paste can) of water and eliminating the brown sugar all together. In addition to that, having the crunch of the bell pepper threw us off as we were eating. Perhaps by tossing in the pepper early and letting it soften we'll be able to alleviate this. It's a good recipe, gives me a launching point for creating sloppy joes, but not a recipe I am going to be adding to my collection over all.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/66803.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
didn't realize that a second review would erase my first one, so this one will sum up both of my previous ones. I doubled the ingredients for the sauce(garlic powder, mustard, ketchup, b sugar). I had to sub red bell for green bell. I added 1tsp worchestershire, 2tsp white vinegar, and a can of tomato paste. I used a nonstick pot and didn't have any issue with sticking, even after simmering down for an hour. I like them thick enough to stand up on the bun, and these were perfect. This is a very sweet recipe, so next time I will probably not double the brown sugar and might experiment with less ketchup and more tomato sauce or paste. Also, I am going to toy with using the crock-pot, though I am weary of sticking. I think ground Bison would be good in this too. All in all, a definite keeper.

text:
I made the recipe exactly as written - as one should when reviewing a recipe.  However, when hubby and I taste tested the finished product we didn't like it at all.  Way too sweet and ketchupy.  We ended up 'doctoring' the meat mixture with chopped jalapenos, more onion and green pepper, more garlic powder and a bit more mustard.  It was better but still too sweet for our tastes.  I think this recipe is better suited to the tastes of kids and young adults.  Thanks for posting the recipe, though!  Hadn't had a sloppy joe in at least 20 years!

text:
This recipe was great - changes I made were that I added only about 2/3 cup ketchup and 2 tbsp of the brown sugar and it was the right level of sweetness for our family; I also used red bell pepper instead of green.  Based on another review, I also added the 1/2 cup water & 1 tbsp quick oats.  We all loved this recipe, even my two year old who are it with noodles instead.  It tasted exactly the way I remember it growing up. In the future, I might add a bit more chopped bell pepper and more oats to add to the nutrition since you could not tell they were in the mix.  We will definitely make this one again!

text:
Delicious!  I even short cutted fairly significantly.  I browned the ground beef with some red bell pepper and dried minced onion.  I drained the fat and eye-balled the addition of ketchup, mustard, brown sugar, garlic powder and s+p, adding more brown sugar than the recipe called for.  I stirred until heated through (didn't simmer for 30 minutes as directed).  It was a yummy and quick lunch. A keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe because I always have these ingredients in the kitchen and its so easy!  I did change it according to other reviewers' suggestions: I doubled the meat and more than doubled the sauce. We don't like bell peppers so I omitted them. I used an entire small yellow onion, and substituted about 1/4 of the ketchup with BBQ sauce- which was a little sweet so I left out the brown sugar.  I ended up adding a little water, all told maybe about 1/2 cup or so, as well as 3-4 tsp apple cider vinegar and 1 baby can of tomato paste. This made a huge amount of very nice, very sloppy joe's!  I also took another person's suggestion and froze servings in a muffin tin to be used up later- great idea!!  I will always double this and will never have to buy the mix again!  Thank You!  Giving 4 stars just cuz I did change it from the original

My husband loved it.  We both hadn't had sloppy joes in years and this was a good, easy dinner.  I made the following changes: I doubled the sauce as others suggested, it's really a must if you want SLOPPY joes.  I also added a tablespoon of minced garlic and about 4-6 ounces of tomato paste.  I didn't have brown sugar so I added 1/4 cup barbeque sauce that had brown sugar in it.  I served it with corn on the cob on the side.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!  It has a lovely, sweet/tangy flavour.  My husband does not like onion or green peppers, so I skipped the peppers and added 1/2 tsp onion powder to the sauce instead.  For the sauce, I did added 1/2 cup ketchup and 1/4 cup BBQ sauce as some suggested.  Although the recipe yeilds 6 servings, we had 4 people eating and small buns.  We were able to get 6 servings, but they were not piled, generous servings, so seconds were not available for everyone.  I will double it next time for feeding more than 3 people.  Excellent recipe!  Never buying the canned stuff again!

This was an excellent recipe, I made it as written first. The only thing I changed the second time was purely a personal thing. I like things a touch spicy so 1 tsp cayenne pepper got tossed in. I also felt that the sugar was tasty but a little much, again for my personal taste, so I cut it down to a single tablespoon. It was a wonderful recipe and with two minor changes its now perfect for me.  I can see this being an incredible hit with kids as is. Its an excellent replacement for a sodium laden can of Manwich, that you can do in literally the same amount of time.

THE ABSOLUTE BEST!!!  I have made this recipe on numerous occasions and always a hit the crowd.  Actually everyone I've made them for agrees that they are the best. THANK YOU for posting this recipe!!!

text:
I thought this recipe was great.  I was afraid I had added too much mustard, because it smelled quite mustard-y while simmering, but once it was put together it was very good (I still might half the mustard next time; it goes a long way).  I was low on ketchup, so I added 1/4 cup water and 1/4 cup BBQ sauce and it was quite tasty.  Great, simple recipe for a weeknight.  Also a good jumping-off point if you like to experiment.  Try it open-face with paper-thin slices of sharp cheddar and red onion on top.

I made this as written the first time and it was a little dry and sweet.  Second time?  I used a full cup of ketchup but it was half Balsamic Ketchup and half BBQ sauce.  I added fresh garlic when browning the meat and then a healthy splash of vinegar when I added the other ingredients.  The vinegar adds that Sloppy Joe 'tang' and takes away some of the sweetness at the same time.  It was perfect and a keeper.

text:
This recipe saved a meal that I was about to throw out!!  I made sloppy joes last night from a recipe in my well known red/white checked cookbook... they were bland and flavorless.  Since this recipe shared many of the ingredients from that recipe I decided to go ahead and add the remaining ingredients that the other recipe didn't have... ketchup, mustard, and brown sugar.  The difference was unbelievable!  I will never try another sloppy joe recipe again.  Actually, I only made sloppy joes because everyone else likes them... I have always hated them.  Not anymore!!  If I could give this more than 5 stars I definitely would!
