text:
I loved this recipe!  I haven't had sloppy joe's in years, but I will definitely be adding this to my easy go to meal list!  

I did make some modifications to the recipe based on what I had in the kitchen and a some of the suggestions here.  Instead of ground beef I used ground chicken (I know, I know, but it is all I had).  It worked fabulously!  

I also scaled down the recipe to make it for one.  I used about 1/4 an onion and 1/4 of a green bell pepper, and 2 tbsp. of ketchup with 1 tbsp. of bbq sauce and 1 tbsp. of water and a little extra mustard.  I followed the rest of the directions exactly (scaled down of course) and thought my joe was perfectly sloppy and delicious! 

Also ate in on two slices of potato bread, which I highly recommend,

As someone else suggested, instead of 3/4 cup of ketchup, I used 1/2 cup of barbecue sauce and 1/4 cup of ketchup, plus a little bit of celery salt, and it was fantastic. I'm not a regular sloppy joe eater, but on a kaiser roll, this recipe might change that. These are SOOOOO Good!!  I was browsing through Allrecipes one day trying to get some inspiration for dinner and found this recipe.  I usually use Manwich when I make sloppy joes, but as some of the other reviewers stated - No More!  I used 1/2 cup of the frozen onion and pepper blend just because that's more convenient for me. text:
I thought this was a great recipe. I've always used Manwich in the past, but my husband and I liked this so much better. I changed this a little to suit our personal tastes: added BBQ sauce in place of part of the ketchup, used extra garlic powder and some Wortchestershire Sauce for more of a kick, and did extra of all the wet ingredients to make more sauce. After it was all cooked through, I put it in the crockpot for a few hours to let the flavors meld together more. It was delicious!

text:
I hate to give such a bad rating, but the proportions in this recipe don't seem right at all. There was not nearly enough sauce for 1 pound of meat, it should be doubled or maybe even tripled.  Also to simmer it for 30 minutes would have been way too long.  I followed the recipe, then when I saw that it wasn't enough sauce I had already run out of ketchup so I had to add water, then I only simmered it for about 10 minutes.  It still tasted pretty good, don't get me wrong, and I will probably make it again, I will just make more sauce next time.

Very good!  Better than the packages I used to buy, and my husband agreed with that.  I did make some little changes.  Instead of all ketchup, I add a 1/4 hp steak sauce, for a little bit of a deeper flavor.  Also I did add a few extra dried herbs and to make it not so thick, I add a little beef stock.  I think next time I will omit the brown sugar for it was a tad sweeter than needed.

I doubled the amount of onions and peppers, and increased the rest of the ingredients to "heaping" simply because the veggie crumbles  don't really have a taste to them. Anyhow this recipe has become one of our favorites in a house of young and old.

text:
I was actually kind of worried because the ingredient list was so small, but I trusted the reviews and gave it a try.  This is the perfect, simple sloppy joe recipe.  No need to make it harder than it needs to be.  My only change was that I added about 1/2 c finely chopped carrot to the beef, onion, and bell pepper mix to add more nutrition.  Oh, I also switched the bell pepper from green to orange because I don't like green bell peppers.  This one is going in the permanent file.  Thanks!

text:
My mother makes these for Halloween night because they are an easy meal to put together, except she makes an "open faced" sloppy joe. To make it fun she takes a Kraft Single slice of cheese and cuts a face into the cheese (triangle for eyes, triange for nose, and a mouth) and then puts it on top of the sloppy joe and microwaves it for a few seconds so that it creates a face on your sloppy joe!

This is a great recipe.  I only use about a half pound of beef because I only have to feed 2.  I have made this many times, using either green, red or yellow peppers and it is perfect. I highly recommend this recipe, especially for families with children.

I really enjoyed this recipe.  It's not all that much different from Manwich, but it allows for more variation in the flavor.  I made the recipe as is, with the exception that I made more of the sauce.  The flavor definitely gets better as it simmers...allow for that and dont expect to cut it short.  Next time, I think I may try adding a little more "heat" to the flavoring.

text:
Dude!  This recipe rocks!  It's super easy and fast to make, and it's delicious.  I made them for my husband's mom and grandmother and they were obsessed!  I use ground turkey instead of beef, I don't drain the juices from the meat, and I double up on all of the ingredients (except the meat), adding 2 teaspoons of worchestershire sauce.  Oh yeah, and don't add salt.  There's enough in the ketchup.  You can also use different coler bell peppers which give off a sweeter flavor. I recommend this recipe to everyone.

text:
One could search for a long time and not find a sloppy joe recipe as good as this one. It was absolutely awesome.  Next time, as others have suggested, I will reduce the brown sugar a bit--maybe by one third or so. No doubt, the sweet flavor is part of the appeal, so we don't want to eliminate it completely; just reduce it a tad.  Beyond that, this sucker is a winner.  It deserves the blue ribbon award for sloppy joes.  I served "Rich and Creamy Tomato Basil" soup with these and it was an exceptional combination.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have three teenagers, 14, 15 and 16 and a husband of 18 years.  I had already prepared 1.75 pounds of ground beef cooked with an onion and had it previously frozen, waiting for a quick week night dinner.  I simply sauted 1 garlic clove (instead of the powder) with 1/2 C green bell pepper (again, previously chopped and frozen, waiting for me.) in 1 Tablespoon of Olive Oil.  Once these were sufficiently cooked, I added my pre-cooked ground beef.  Once warmed, I added 1 cup Ketchup, 3 teaspoons brown sugar and about a 2 teaspoons of mustard, since I had increased the amount of ground beef.  My girls HATE canned & envelope Sloppy Joes mixes.  They've never liked Sloppy Joes because of those prepared mixes and my husband joined them in their dislike.  Tonight, they fell in love with Sloppy Joes!  I haven't heard the end about how great this was!  I served it with homemade Mac & Cheese and a pea salad.  Week night dinner made easy!  Thanks Tamara for a recipe that my family finally agrees on and likes!  AWESOME!!!

What a fantastic jumping off point!!!! I made a double batch as we have a large family. I followed the original recipe ingredients but changed the brown sugar to 1 from 3 and I used a can of tomato sauce. We like alot of flavor so as it simmered I kept adding spices here and there (onion powder and garlic powder) until it was just perfect. It was thick and sloppy and my whole family devoured it! Don't be afraid to play with it until it suits your taste - its a perfect base sauce!A+++ on this one!

text:
This is a good recipe.  I had made it with 3 pounds of hamburger.  I initially was going to use manwich but realized after frying the beef that I only had one can so here is what I did:  I used the 1 can of manwich and scaled the recipe for 12.  I did not have any onion or garlic powder so I used dried minced onion and dried minced garlic.  Other than those substitutions I made it according to the rest of ingredients and directions.  This is a really good flavorful sloppy joe.  Our boys really loved them as well.  Because of the rising costs of canned goods (i.e. Manwich) I will stay with this one and save some extra money.  Thanks for the great recipe.  A really must try.

text:
I found this recipe a while ago and loved it! The first time I made it my husband assumed it was from a can. He didn't believe me when I told him I made it from scratch. I have tweaked it a bit. I took another user's advice and used fresh minced garlic (instead of the powder) -- I love fresh garlic so I use 2-3 cloves. Just saute them for a few minutes with the onions before adding the beef. I also play w/the amount of ketchup. I noticed one reviewer said it tasted like ketchup and ground beef. I would agree that it's possible for that to happen but if you balance it to your tasting by testing, you'll be fine. I leave out the pepper because I don't like green peppers :). At the end I add a dash of hot sauce!

I have made this twice now and my whole family loved it (even my picky 2 and 4 year old kids!).  My husbands only complaint was that I didn't make more! text:
A very easy recipe and one that allows you to be creative.  Based on other reviews, I cut down the amount of brown sugar to 1 tsp.  I also wanted to liven-up the taste (so that the sauce wouldn't be too ketchup-y), so I just added 1/2 cup of ketchup and 1/4 cup of Heinz 57 sauce.  It added just the right of oomph.

text:
OK, but needs some work.  I started off following the recipe as is, and there wasn't nearly enough sauce for the meat.  Took other reviewer's advice and doubled the sauce.  My end result was very thick and pasty, and basically just tasted like ground beef and ketchup.  I might try this again, but use tomato juice or tomato sauce instead of ketchup so that the flavor isn't so overwhelming.  Also, I found that the 30 minute cook time was a bit long.  My beef was very dried out.  Good potential, but needs work.

text:
This is an GREAT sloppy joe recipe. The whole family loved it! I scaled it to serve 10 and it was gone in one evening. I had to make a second batch the next day because they wanted more. I had put in a little extra brown sugar because I like my sloppy joe's on the sweet side and also added a a couple of dashes of worchestshire sauce. I did add a little water as it was cooking to prevent it from drying out as previous reviewers had recommended. Turned out perfect.....just what I was looking for!

text:
A really great recipe and so easy to make.  We all agreed we liked it better than the recipe I had been using for years.  Like so many previous reviewers noted, I found the sauce got very dry while cooking so I added a little bit more ketchup and just a little bit of water.  I did not add any salt to the recipe as there is plenty in the ketchup.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7617849.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Meh- I found this to be rather bland and also too sweet (ketchup is plenty sweet, plus brown sugar) which was unfortunate, because I used it to make my own raised  Angus for a large crowd of hungry wrestlers and both the cow and the boys deserved better.. It is not a Manwich replacement if that’s what you’re after- it’ snot bad, but it’s not great, either. I believe this would be much improved with a little vinegar, a dash of Frank’s or other hot sauce (or a little cayenne or chili flake, just for a mild kick, not for heat unless that’s your thing). Instead of onion or minced onion I would consider some dry French onion soup mix (I use it all the time,, crushed and always have half a pouch in the pantry) or some Worcestershire. It definitely needs some savory to balance the sweet- some ketchup could be replaced with plain tomato sauce, or perhaps some bottled chili sauce. I will keep looking for a Sloppy recipe that does it for us.

There are better recipes out there that are still just as easy. Too much ketchup plus all the brown sugar made this one too sweet and lacking flavor. I made many adjustments, but they weren't calculated enough to include here. If you were raised on ketchup, have a sweet tooth, and want something super quick and easy with ingredients you likely have on hand, then this will work for you, but I won't be making it again.

Display Name:
Trish Coulter Farano

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe for the last few years both as it is published and with a few modifications.  It's become the "go-to" sloppy joe recipe in our home. Per another reviewer, a dash of Worcestershire sauce is a nice addition as well.
I often try to bump up the vegetables in recipes, so frequently add grated carrot, summer squash/zucchini, finely chopped celery and/or parsley to the mixture. I like to make it earlier in the day, or the night before and reheat. Once simmered for a bit, the vegetables melt in. 

I usually use about half of the brown sugar called for, but that's just me. I don't think most people will think it is too sweet as is.  This is quick and easy, doubles up very well, and freezes well. I find you can get about six sandwiches from the pound of ground beef.

text:
Love this recipe with it's basic ingredients you can build on to make it your own.  I used 1/2 ground beef and 1/2 ground turkey,  1/2 cup ketchup and 1/4 cup bbq sauce, skipped the brown sugar, added 1 tsp Worcestershire Sauce.  After browning the meat and veg I threw everything in my crock pot for a couple of hours on low.  Added some beef broth at the end to make it a little more sloppier.  Hello 70's comfort food!  So good!

text:
This was better than I originally thought it would be. The only sloppy joe i have made was from a packet. I made a few changes. I used a red bell pepper since I didn’t have a green one. I like the flavor of onion, so I chopped about a third of a cup, used a heaping half cup of ketchup and a little shy of a quarter cup bbq sauce. While everything was simmering, I sprinkled more garlic powder and added onion powder. I spooned mine over a junior kaiser roll and my husband had his over an open baked potato. I would definitely ask this again!

country:
None
text:
I have never liked Sloppy Joes until this recipe. After tasting the basic recipe, I did add just a bit of the other ingredients suggest by others to increase the complexity of flavors. I added a half teaspoon of white vinegar,  a teaspoon of War sauce. a half cup more ketchup, a 1/4 cup chili sauce, a tablespoon of chipotle mustard, and a half cup of water, a few shakes of cayenne, and I simmered it for a half hour more.  I served this on grilled brioche buns. Hubs really liked it after he got over the shock of me actually making Sloppy Joes.

text:
This is what Sloppy Joe's are supposed to taste like! I have made several items from Allrecipes, but this is the first one that was rave worthy. I made the first batch exactly as written -  which is what you're supposed to do, right? As excellent as it was, it was a little loose and crumbly. The second batch I eliminated the brown sugar and added 1/4 cup BBQ sauce. It was very good as well and had a nice stickiness, but the BBQ flavor dominated and took over. I am going to make 20 pounds of the original recipe for a family reunion, and add beef broth as necessary to make it a little more moist. Thank you for posting such a wonderful, easy, quick, timeless recipe.

text:
Very good. My suggestions though. 2 tsp of brown sugar instead of 3 (way too sweet with 3). Also, one thing that helped this immensely was adding 1-2 tsp of Frank’s Red Hot. It doesn’t make it spicy (unless you want to add enough to make it spicy), but it takes some of the ketchup taste away, and gives it a bolder flavor. I highly recommend making those changes.

userID:
7224802
Display Name:
misterchi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:

20

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/764579.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
as many other reviewers have already said, this is a good base recipe for joes that allows for as much or as little riffing as you want. with that in mind, i varied slightly from the recipe (i almost never follow a recipe to the letter), but kept the spirit intact.

to begin with, i started my veggies first because i wanted to ensure that the peppers and onions were well cooked. next, i added about 1tsp of smoked paprika, thyme (dried) and cumin. i skipped the ketchup, brown sugar and mustard and went straight for my favorite bottled barbeque sauce, which already has the right balance of sweetness that i'm looking for. i also added a couple of drops of hot sauce for just a hint of heat. the end result is a slightly sweet, slightly smoky, well flavored meat mix that will leave just a whisper of heat on your tongue.

to serve, i use hoagy rolls (which cuts down on the sloppy part) cheddar cheese slices and either pickle chips or  sweet relish and tomato slices.

Rating:
5

text:
I really loved this recipe, but tweaked it a bit for my family’s own taste.  I honestly followed all of the instructions listed, but added about 4 oz. of beer, 2 tbsp of strawberry jelly, 3 tbsp of spicy bbq sauce, 1 tbsp of steak seasoning and about 2 tbsp of corn starch to thicken it up.  I love the base recipe but it is a bit bland so I decided to spice it up a bit with some extra sweet and spicy additives.  Try it out and see what you think!

country:
None
text:
Great foundation for Jose' Messias. Not fond of green peppers, so I skipped those. Substituted  some Sweet Baby Ray Hickory & Brown Sugar BBQ sauce for about a quarter of the ketchup, splashed some Worcestershire  sauce into the ground beef before browning it, and used fresh garlic (4 cloves) instead of  powder, adding them when the meat was mostly done browning.
When I added the sauce to the meat, I also spiked it with some hot flakes a friend concocts, some sweet relish, paprika, curry powder, celery seed, cumin,  and turmeric. Simmered it down to a good consistency and demolished it. I loved the tip about freezing it in a muffin tin, but there really wasn't enough to worry about freezing.

text:
My husband and I truly loves this recipe. It reminds us of life before our kids, who have all grown up and moved away. I did make a few adjustments to the ingredients. I changed the mustard to 1 tablespoon, the ketchup to 1 cup, and added 1/2 to 1 cup of water. After combining the rest of the ingredients, I simmered it all for about 30 minutes.  We sometimes burn our mouths because we can’t wait to eat. I serve ours on toast or buns.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is good no matter what you do to it. I've made it per the recipe, and then made it based on what I had around or felt like adding. It's always a good, easy meal. Good for game day, good for crowds, good for a quick weeknight dinner. I generally make it with ground turkey not beef. I sometimes cut out the brown sugar and ketchup and just use bottled BBQ sauce and some tomato sauce or even leftover pasta sauce. I like veggies, so if I have limp celery or tomatoes I chop that up and throw in as well. And whether I put it in the pot or on the sandwich, I always add any kind of cheese I have on hand -- chedder, colby, muenster, even mozz. This has been added to my Old Faithful list.

text:
Best Sloppy Joes EVER!  Although,  I did alter somewhat.  I did not include green pepper (picky eaters in my fam,) used 3/4 cup water instead of Ketchup (too much sugar & preservatives in Ketchup,) used 2 tsp. of brown sugar instead of 3, and used 1 (6 oz.) can of tomato paste (more lycopene than ketchup.)   It was DELISH!!!!

text:
This was a hit in our house! My husband loved it and the bell peppers and onion just made everything come together. I may just add some more peppers, or even a red pepper for a kick next time! I only added about half of the brown sugar, and a little bit more ketchup. Others suggested adding a little barbecue sauce which I may try next time! I substituted ground beef for ground turkey breast.  They key is to not overcook it and if needed, add a little water. Delish!

I don't plan to buy the store canned sloppy joe mix again but I will keep making this! My hubby and I liked it alot!

I've tried several other sloppy joes recipes from this site and this is by far the best! I doubled the recipe and mixed together a pound of lean ground beef and a pound of ground sausage and my family said they love this recipe better than any other I've tried. text:
Been making sloppy Joes forever. Taste even better as sloppy seconds the next day. If you like to make them with chili sauce rather than just plain catsup, just add a bit of horseradish to the catsup and voila! you have chili sauce taste. 

Always finely diced green pepper for added taste and I throw in a can of V-8 (12 oz.)

Cook the entire batch down until it almost dries out, but does not burn. 

I like good old American cheese on mine.

This is a very good recipe.  I did tweak it just a bit, and added some celery seed (1/2 tsp) and chili powder (1/2 tsp) .  Other then that,followed the recipe to the letter.  Simmer at the lowest level you have on your stove, and watch it closely.  
Serve it on the freshest, cheapest hamburger buns you can find. Just like Momma used to make!

city:

country:
None
text:
We make this frequently and my grandchildren beg for it. I incorporate many of the changes mentioned by others depending on what I have in the kitchen. Less sweet? Use less sugar and sub in some molasses. Sub tomato paste for some of the ketchup. Less fat? Use very lean ground beef or ground turkey. Rinse the browned beef with warm water. A little more kick? Sub in some chili sauce or chili powder.
We serve it one of four ways. . .again depending on what's in the house. 1. Sloppy Joes  2. Sloppy Tacos (fun!). 3. Put it in a flat dish and mix up some corn bread, spread it over the top and bake at 400° for 20 min or so  4. Make a nasty old "blue box" of macaroni and cheese. Put it in a flat baking pan. Spread Sloppy Joe mixture on top. Heat at 375° to 400° for 20-30 minutes. (The spicy/sweet and creamy/cheesy play off of each other beautifully!)
Thank you for submitting this recipe and thanks to the rest of you for your great ideas!
NOTES:  I always add 3/4C of finely diced celery. It adds some nutrients, fiber, and moisture and limits the need for additional salt. It doesn't change the taste.
If you want to freeze an extra recipe (or 3!) we find that a slightly mounded 1/3C scoop in a muffin tin is exactly right for a regular hamburger bun. OR place mixture in a ziplock bag and flatten it to the thickness you like on your  bun. Close the bag and chill it. Then score it on the outside in the size you want for your bun and freeze - I use a chopstick for scoring. This has the adv

text:
I thought it was awesome! It sounds good as-is; however, I made a few changes:

A) lean ground turkey in place of beef B) no salt, I just peppered the meat prior to browning
C) I increased the amount of green pepper and onion just because I was feeling lazy
D) Instead of ketchup, I made my own concoction:
- 1 cup tomato paste
- 1 tbsp Splenda for baking
- 1 tsp white vinegar
- 1 cup vegetable stock

text:
Just a great basic recipe.   As is, it is a little bit sweet for my taste, but always gets eaten.  Only change I make is to drop the brown sugar and cut the ketchup in half, replacing the missing ketchup with barbeque sauce.  This cuts the sweetness.  Since I usually have 5 or 6 BBQ sauces on hand, it gives a fun chance to play with the flavor by choice of sauce or combining them.

I'm so glad I found this recipe. This will definitely go into our regular rotation.  I took the advice from a few of the comments (omit brown sugar, add 1/2 cup water, use 1/2 cup ketchup and 1/4 cup bbq sauce, 1/4 tsp dry mustard instead of prepared yellow mustard, cook on low for 20 minutes). text:
Like many on here, I really don't like it when someone reviews something, gives it 5 stars, and then lists the eleventy-bajillion additions/changes they made. As is, it's a very simple, decent sloppy joe recipe. I thought it was a bit too...tangy? The vinegar overtones were too much, so I made the following additions:

I added some worcestershire sauce to mellow it out, some ground mustard, and water to let it cook down and mellow. 

With those additions, it would be a 4 or a 5--but this is a good starter recipe.

text:
I made this for my son who really wanted Sloppy Joe's & he loved it! We really liked it too. It reminds me of another one of our favorite recipes that we make often, which we refer to as "Best Ever Meatloaf" you can google it just like that but its a delicious cheesy meatloaf and the sauce topping is ketchup, brown sugar & yellow mustard. I highly recommend it! as for this recipe, I added a half cup of water to 2.5 lb meat version of recipe, I also pretty much always use ground turkey rather than ground beef, in meatloaf too, I've made it both ways but we actually prefer ground turkey to ground beef now. As for reviews that say its too sweet (brown sugar) or not sweet enough, etc., you know your families tastes best :) this type of recipe is simple enough that you can start off with less and add to taste and it won't effect it at all. Thanks for this recipe!

userID:
20851325
Display Name:
Mai
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sloppy Joe's aren't my personal favorite but my brother loves them. I made this recipe for the first time and it was super easy. I did make a few adjustments to meet his palate. First, I added just a touch of olive oil to the pan to add texture to the meat. I also added less onion since he's not a huge fan but added just a hint of onion powder. I added salt and pepper to the meat as it was browning to give it a deeper flavor. As that was browning, I personally prefer to add the sauce ingredients in a separate bowl and whisk them so they fully incorporate together. I added all of the ingredients including about three tablespoons BBQ sauce. That really made the difference! I added it to the meat, onions and peppers and left it on low for the recommended 30 mins. I steamed some slider buns and he LOVED it! It was so easy and most of the ingredients we had at the house. I highly recommend it!!
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
Great great. I have made this for the last 5 years. For my family as well as my Firehouse. Have made it exactly the way this says and is great. But I have been expanding it. Add 1/2 lb of chopped up skirt steak, way more peppers and onions (all three colors) and shaved fresh garlic. Just add 2 more teaspoons of brown sugar and another 1/4 cup of ketchup. Give it a try it's great both ways.

text:
Best. sloppy. joes. ever.   I made the following changes:

1) I used three minced garlic cloves instead of reconstituted and I sauteed it with the ground beef, onions and green pepper.
2) I used 3/4 cup of diced onion and green pepper 
3) I used SPICY BROWN MUSTARD instead of plain
4) I doubled the sauce, which produced the perfect meat to sauce ratio.  

So good, they're on the menu for next week, as well!

Just made this exactly as written, well kind of, and LOVED IT! 

I made a few changes, (one  by mistake).  Like another reviewer, I used 1/2  cup of ketchup and 1/4 cup of bbq  sauce.  The 2nd was that I read the recipe wrong and after adding (2) tablespoons of  brown sugar, realized it was only (3) teaspoons.  I also added a little bit of water, to thin just a tad, to make a little more loose!  No matter though, it was delicious to me and I absolutely loved it!  Put it on a grilled onion roll with a slice of American cheese on the bottom roll!  Ate  with sweet potato fries.  OMG...so yummy!  Thank you for sharing!  This is now my Sloppy Joe go to recipe!  :-)

This is really good and really easy to make! The only thing I do differently is I use 1/2 a cup of ketchup and add 1/2 a cup of tomato sauce. I find that just using 3/4 of a cup of ketchup leaves this on the dry side. I also use minced garlic instead of garlic powder. When I added in the tomato sauce, my husband actually thought I had bought the canned version because it tasted so similar!

I got up early to make this for a pitch in at church. I made this as it is written. I used 6 pounds of hamburger so I multiplied the ingredients by 6. The only thing I do not like is the overwhelming mustard taste. We all stood around the skillet, individual spoon in hand & tried it. TOO MUCH MUSTARD. I've put extra brown sugar & 2 oz. of tomatoe paste & it's better but the mustard taste still lays on the back of your tongue. I hope they like it at church. If the mustard was omitted in the recipe I would've given it 5 stars.

I tried this recipe and hubby actually think it tastes better than Manwich. I cooked the recipe exactly except for substituting red peppers for green peppers. (It's what I had on hand). Coming from a family of Southern cooks who likes their barbecue sweeter next time I will add an additional 1/4 c brown sugar (I added the same amount to every can of Manwich). Hubby prefers the recipe as written so I'm rating it four stars. Today I'm making a larger batch (5 pounds hamburger) and planning to freeze it to make this as convenient as keeping Manwich on hand.

text:
I give it five stars. It was a simple ingredient easy to make and gave me plenty of left overs. My boyfriend is picky with what he eats and has had some nasty homemade sloppy Joe's. He loved what I made. I didn't fully follow the recipe. I used honey mustard for sweetness instead of brown sugar and instead of ketchup I used chopped tomatoes in sauce and jack Daniels spicy and bold bbq sauce. I also added red pepper for flavor along with the green pepper. The combo made a semi sweet and spicy tomato sauce that thickened to make the perfect sloppy joe!

text:
I doubled the recipe for my family of 6. I however did not double the ketchup, instead added in chili sauce for the double. I also added extra garlic powder and extra black pepper too. One thing I would suggest is not to drain your meat completely ( I saved about 1/2 cup liquid)  I also used 95% lean ground beef so it was not greasy. The extra liquid is needed so your sauce doesn't dry out, it is after all it's called  "Sloppy" Joe. It turned out delicious. No more ready made canned sauce !

I'm not a huge sloppy joe fan. I just have never really enjoyed them. Until now. My husband wanted sloppy joes for dinner  and I figured that I had tortured him with a lot of chicken recently, so I came to look. I had everything but the bell pepper so  I figured I'd give it a shot. We all loved it. Even my recently-picky son inhaled it. My anti-sloppy joe self? I'm looking forward to lunch tomorrow!

I measured out the ketchup and then eyeballed the rest. Served it on potato buns and it was incredible. I knew it was really good when my husband mentioned that maybe I should make it for his coworkers during their next busy time and they don't have time to leave for lunch. That's one heck of a compliment!

text:
I thought this was delicious!  I followed some of the changes recommended by other reviewers because I thought I would like them.  I made 1-1/2 times the sauce, used 1/2 c ketchup and 1/4 c BBQ sauce instead of all ketchup and no brown sugar because of the sweetness added by the BBQ sauce.  I also added a couple of TB water so there would be enough juice to let it simmer at least 20 minutes.  I am freezing a couple of portions and expect it to work great.  Next time I will double the recipe as I wanted more leftovers!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. It was a bit too sweet for us the first time I made it, so the second time I skipped the sugar and it was much better. I also didn't have any green pepper, and it didn't seem to make a difference in the flavor. For those watching their salt and/or sugar/HFCS intake, skip the commercial ketchup and make your own. It is just tomato paste, water, vinegar, sugar, salt, and onion/garlic powder. Making your own will allow you to control the amount of salt and sugar.

text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious. I did make a few changes. I took another reviewers advice and I substituted some of the ketchup with bbq sauce which eliminated the need for the sugar. I also used a jalapeño because i like my food a bit spicy. I also substituted 1 cup of the ground beef for a cup of bacon bits. I cooked the bacon bits in a separate pot and when my beef was browned I drained the water and added it to the pot with the bacon. it added a wonderful crunchy elements which i enjoyed. yes not the conventional sloppy Joe but I like to make twists on recipes. I completely recommend you try this recipe it is amazing and I definitely make again

userID:

Display Name:
Jules

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/28647.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor of this is great - It's spot on.  Might just be the way I remember it as a kid, but I like my sloppy joe to be runnier with  a real tomato component to it, so I added some left over plain canned tomato sauce and canned diced tomatoes (in all, maybe a 50/50 split of each, totaling ~1 1/4 cup). This dilutes the awesome flavor though, so I had to up all the ingredients to get it back to how it was. The sauce and the tomatoes addition make it truly 'sloppy'! Also used Beyond Beef crumbles (it's made from pea protein, and then added 1/4 c water to give more moisture) since our family isn't huge on real ground beef. Served on slightly toasted buns with mac 'n' cheese. Yum.

Display Name:
audlyn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2585283.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe but it is quite a small one. I doubled it or tripled it both times I made it, depending on the amount of ground beef  I had. I actually measured it - when I did 2.5x the recipe I got exactly ten 1/2 cup portions which makes a generous but not too-sloppy Sloppy Joe. I doubled the garlic powder just because I think there is no such thing as too much garlic, and replaced 1/3 of the ketchup with BBQ sauce. I think it would be definitely too sweet with only ketchup, and in fact was plenty sweet as is, plus the BBQ sauce adds rich flavours. Next time will cut brown sugar in half. No salt as there is plenty in bbq sauce, ketchup etc. Also like many others I added about 1/3 c water per "recipe" in order to cook it for the 30 min. We served it on toasted buns with garlic parmesean mayo and shredded cheese. Our whole family loved it!

text:
This was very tasty.  The entire family liked it.  I did not have the onion or bell pepper so I just left them out and added a touch of onion powder to give the beef that onion flavor. Next time I prepare this one however, I will double the wet ingredients.  I did not have enough sauce to let this simmer as the direction state.  It was more like, keep warm until the rest of dinner was ready. If not double, I will go ahead and prepare the rest of dinner along side the meat mixture so it is fresh.

text:
I loved it! I followed some of the suggestions that people gave such as using a 1/2 cup ketchup and 1/4 cup Sweet Baby Rays to give it a little BBQ taste.  After sautéing the beef, onions and peppers  I added 1/2 cup lentils and 1/2cup Beef Broth and put it all in the crock pot for 3-4 hrs on high.  It was incredible! The lentils gave it a heartier taste and my husband loved it!

NOTE: Really about 4.5 STARS, but really very good, with my two changes as follow: I browned the beef and drained the grease in a colander. Using the same pan, I sautéed the onion before returning the beef and adding the rest of the ingredients. I used more brown sugar (about 1 and one-half TBLS) and 1 tsp. of Worcestershire Sauce.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was committed to making sloppy joes tonight only to find that I was out of my convenient go-to sloppy joe mix. In a rush to find a recipe that called for ingredients I had on-hand, I came across this one. I have to say it was a hit - especially with the kids.  Super quick and easy to make and tasty. I think this will now be my go-to - why mess with a mix when it's this easy.  The only changes I would make is that I would use a less sweet ketchup - and slightly less brown sugar. I upped the garlic for our taste. Another note is that I made it with a meat substitute and you would be hard pressed to tell the difference.  Overall, a great basic recipe that can be personalized as you like. Will definitely make again.

text:
I like this quite a bit, but I leave out the brown sugar. Even without it, the sauce borders on too sweet for my tastes. This isn't a saucy sloppy joe recipe; most of the liquid evaporates during cooking. I personally prefer that over a runny sauce. Bonus: it's so easy to throw together! On lazy days I just substitute 1T dried minced onion for the chopped onion and leave out the bell pepper.

text:
Homemade sloppy joes make people so happy.  Whenever I make serve them, people are impressed that I've made them from scratch, rather than from a can.  The secret is that it's just as easy to make sloppy joes from scratch as it is to make them from a can, and they are much, much better when they are homemade.  I like to put bread and butter pickle slices onto each sandwich.  It adds a sweet tang.  This is a solid and easy recipe which will impress your friends and family.

Hadn't made Sloppy Joe's in a very long time.  This recipe got my attention.  It was very good, but I did make a few changes.  I used ground turkey to begin with, added some chopped celery, cut back on the catsup and added 1/4 cup of cocktail sauce and about 1 Tbsp of Sriracha sauce and 1 Tbsp of Worcestershire. I've made this a few times and my family loved it.  We used to like Manwich but the taste has changed over the years and we do not like the allspice taste that it has.  For those complaining this is too sweet, check your ketchup labels and choose a lower sugar variety. We use Hunts and it doesn't taste too sweet to us.  If you can't stand canned sloppy joe or one made from a packet, definitely give this a try.  Simple and delicious!

text:
I used 1/2 cup ketchup and 1/4 cup BBQ sauce and it seemed too sweet. Added healthy dose of Worcester and a few capfuls of cider vinegar then a bit more ketchup to cut the sweetness.  I'm glad I left out the brown sugar.  It was good but not great.  I think it was still a bit sweeter than I expected.  I don't think I would use BBQ sauce at all next time.  I'll make it again and add more onion. Coleslaw was a nice side dish.

text:
This was my first time making sloppy joes and it came out great. I used a whole medium onion, instead of just a 1/4th of a cup. I also used 1/2 cup of chopped green bell pepper, 1/2 cup of red bell pepper, a tablespoon of the yellow mustard, and 1/4 tsp of salt. I also used turkey instead of beef. Everything else was done as written. Cant go wrong with this recipe. This will defiantly be a stable in my house.

text:
I rarely "cook" dinner (order pizza, boil hot dogs, etc....), it's primarily my wife who truly cooks, so I decided to make this to help more in the kitchen. The hardest part of this experiment was sticking to the recipe - my wife was very skeptical because it varied from her usual ground beef prep methods. In the end, she loved it, and my kids loved it. This was VERY easy for a scrub like me, it is absolutely delicious. I followed the directions exactly except for one minor change - I didn't use salt and pepper, I added about a teaspoon of Lawry's Seasoning Salt. The consistency was perfect (for us), but others who like it really sloppy will need to adjust (don't ask me how, I suck at this). I read a comment where someone replaced the brown sugar with BBQ sauce, so I'm anxious to try that version next. 1LB of ground beef was enough for about 5-6 sandwiches, so I'll probably do 2LB next. But as is, this recipe is a winner.

Display Name:
ceh
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe probably 100 times now, the kids always ask for it.  I do make it much more simply now for time and because it still tastes great even when cutting some things.  I usually throw frozen ground beef in the crock-pot in the morning since I never remember to defrost meat and then throw a bunch of garlic (powder or fresh whatever I have) on it with onion powder.  My husband doesn't like chunks of onion so I use onion powder.  I let it cook then drain it off.  I then toss in more garlic (I LOVE garlic), enough ketchup for it to be saucy, a couple of spoonfuls of sugar, and a squirt of mustard.  Dinner is served.  I have made this in massive quantities during moving and just left it in the crock-pot and all the guys just helped themselves during the day.  Also when having people over I will leave this in a crock-pot so the kids can just get more whenever they are hungry.  Great dish, I used to hate sloppy joes before this recipe.

text:
It was easy to make and tasty, but I also tweaked the recipe.  I used some BBQ sauce, which has some sugar, as does the ketchup.  I used a little brown sugar, also.  I thought it needed a little heat, to counteract all the sweet elements.  I added a few drops of tabasco sauce and a bit of chili powder.  It did not make it very spicy, but I thought the flavor was more balanced.

text:
I have made this recipe over 20 times. We have five kids and we all love it. I always double it and when I double it I use 1 cup ketchup and 1/2 cup bbq (sweet baby rays original) and I throw in about 1/3 bottle of Heineken. Simmer for 20 minutes with the lid on and them ten minutes with the lid off and turn the heat up to cook off the liquid.

flyty28

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic flavor and super easy to throw together. Dad said it was "way better than that canned stuff".  Big praise from him. I generally don't tinker much with recipes but recently I was put on a very low sodium diet and have had to start altering recipes to accommodate it.  To avoid using salt I made the following adjustments: used Heinz no salt ketchup, added 2/3 cup diced celery, 2 tsps minced garlic and 1 tsp worsteshire sauce.  After simmering for about 15 minutes I added 1/2 cup of water and a 1/2 tsp vinegar.  After another 15-20 minutes the consistency and flavor were perfect.  Sodium content per serving (before bun) about 150 mg for 4 ounces.  Thanks for a GREAT recipe!

I did alter it a bit for lack of ingredients.  I used ground turkey instead and used minced garlic because I keep forgetting to buy some more powder.

I did have to change it in the middle of cooking because I ended up adding more ground turkey since it didn't look like enough for our whole family and I didn't measure out the ingredients again  and instead just eyeballed it which led to too much mustard (oops!) and I hate mustard so I ended up added a bunch more of the sugar to help it and it tastes wonderful!
If I had left it the same with just the one pound ground turkey, the flavor was still a bit mustard-y for me since I don't like mustard, but still a great sloppy joe flavor.

This was my first time making sloppy joes and they came out fine. I used 1.5 lbs of ground beef, so upped the amounts of everything by a little. Used 3/4 cup of ketchup and 1/4 cup of BBQ sauce--was a little dry this time (esp reheating leftovers), so might up those amounts next time. Tasty joes, though. Thanks to OP and other contributors for sharing:)

text:
This was great, My boyfriend does not like sloppy joes,but my kids love them, so I look for a good recipe.  After reading the reviews I browned one jalapeno and part of a red salsa pepper(no seeds) into the beef mixture. I omitted the brown sugar. I added 1/4c. bbq sauce and only 1/2c. ketchup. It was very good, and the peppers gave it a nice kick, but not too hot. My kids still loved it, and so did the man who doesn't like sloppy joes!

text:
After reading several reviews (I always check to see what "tweeks" were made and how many people agreed)I made this recipe exactly as is except I added 1 tbsp of Worstechire sauce. These are by far the best sloppy joes my husband and I have ever had. We were amazed at how flavorful they were with the smallest amount of ingredients. I am going to make these again and follow a tip I read which is to make a bigger batch, freeze the leftovers in a muffin tin, once frozen, pop out, cover individually and store for future use - one muffin tin size is a perfect bun-size portion.

text:
Thanks for the effort but this was not what I was looking for. I love Sloppy Joes and I was really craving them so you would think I would like this.  This is NOTHING like traditional Sloppy Joes.  The mustard and too much brown sugar destroy it. This was sickly sweet with a horrible bitter aftertaste. My daughter refused to eat it. I was able to add some tomato paste and mellow it out enough to be edible, but if I were to do it again I would leave out the mustard and cut the brown sugar in half if not remove it entirely as catsup already has a ridicules amount of sugar in the first place.

The base recipe was just okay. However, with some modifications it's a 5 star recipe. I didn't have green bell peppper so I used red, other than that I followed the recipe exactly. text:
Personally, this is the second best recipe I've cooked. My first best was a recipe of Boeuf Bourguignon a la Julia Child. This recipe is perfect and it's a hundred times better on the second day/when it's cold in the fridge.
If I can give a tip to everyone who wants to cook it, just DON'T use hamburger buns, especially wonder bread. It will taste awful. I recommend using kaiser buns or large home made buns (can be hamburger buns really, but don't use branded buns. Use store/home buns). 
Enjoy! :)

text:
My family loved these and I will never buy a sauce in a can again.  It is an easily adaptable recipe.  I cook all my ground beef ahead of time so I can buy in bulk (on a budget) and so I can thaw and go (working mom).  I used dried onion, a blend that I bought at one of those parties, and a little garlic bread seasoning in place of the garlic powder.  I reconstituted the onions and then threw everything in a big microwaveable bowl and mixed well.  I microwaved until heated through.  My kids ate seconds and went on and on about these.  So easy.

text:
Great recipe . . . with a few minor tweaks.  To start I tripled the quantities to ensure that there would be leftovers.  Instead of using all ketchup I used 50% ketchup and 1 5.5 oz can of tomatoe paste.  I then added 1 1/2 tablespoons of white wine vinegar and 1 1/2 tablespoons of Manuka honey.  The end result was our kids asking for seconds and thirds . . . not has much leftover as I had planneed ;)

text:
Fast, easy, and tasty.  I use it to make popovers.  Just buy(I use Grands)or make your own biscuit dough, roll it, stuff it with the mixture,  pinch it closed, and bake at 350 for 20 min or until light brown.  It makes it easy for little kids to eat and you can freeze any leftovers for a quick snack or lunch later.

I had some leftover meatloaf(i know, its almost unheard of) that had 2 tbsp onion powder, salt/pepper, bread crumbs and 1 egg. I used probably 3 tbsp ketchup, 1/2-1cup bbq sauce (just what i had in the fridge). userID:
4211236
Display Name:
Muscle Jock Chef
isPro:
False
followersCount:
17
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
52
favoritesCount:
578
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1440020.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK this is one of the most versatile & easy recipes to make. Of course I altered this recipe, I use mostly ground turkey I was wanting to use all turkey but I needed a little more than what came in the pack so I bought .75lb of 80% lean ground beef to mix in. I chopped up onion and half a red bell pepper , but in hot skillet of 2 tbs spoon of olive oil then sprinkled it with salt.. I cooked them veggies down to really carmelized and soft as my family don't like crunchy vegetables in food.

I then tossed in the ground turkey which was marinated with worchester sauce. I brown the ground turkey while added in garlic powder, onion powder, and some steak sauce. After the turkey was all cooked I added in the rest of the ground beef browned & cooked it more with turkey & veggies to infuse flavor into the meat. I then added some more worchester sauce. After all the meat was cooked good I then pour contents in strainer. 
Now for the sauce I put in half a can of tomato paste, then used some barbecue sauce.. and I eyeballed the amount of mustard to use in the sauce so I could say I used 2 tables spoon. I then added garlic powder & steak seasoning season mix. I also added 1/4 cup of Apple cider vinegar  & I used barbecue sauce (omitted the sugar element" because Ketchup or barbecue sauce carry  enough sugar, all cooked over medium heat. The key to the sauce is taste as you go. I then added cup of water to make sure enough sauce. I added back the meat into sauce simmer for 20 min & serve

I have made these for years using deer burger & sometimes Italian sausage,  except I add about 3 splashes of Worcestrershire, & use about 1/2 cup of brown sugar instead of 3 tsp. I also don't add pepper, or garlic salt. Love them! 

So, I had to choose a  recipe from Allrecipes with ground beef as an ingredient and “make it over” using Johnsonville’s Italian Sausage, This is the one I chose. Like I said before, I loved them. I also chose to use French bread with Italian Seasonings that I butter toasted on both sides on a flat grill.

text:
This is my go-to recipe for Sloppy Joes.  If I'd known how easy it was all along, I would have never purchased a single can of Manwich.  The recipe doesn't require exactness.  I can dump some onions and peppers, season my ground beef with garlic salt while it cooks and then eyeball the ketchup, mustard and brown sugar.  I like to use ketchup without high fructose corn syrup to help keep it a little healthier.

text:
Seriously good! Best sloppy joe I've ever made and cannot even compare to the one from the can- yuck. Anyway, I followed previous reviewers and did 3/4 cup of ketchup, 1/4 cup of sweet baby ray's barbecue sauce. I also put the onion, pepper and a little garlic in the blender to make my veggies more like a salsa. Sauteed the veggies, added the ground turkey then once done drained the liquid and added the rest of the ingredients from the list. I added a little water to help it simmer longer. You could not tell I used turkey at all! It came out amazing!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been craving sloppy joes, but I didn't want to buy the canned stuff because of the bad ingredients and amount of salt used in it. I used ground turkey instead of beef so it was a bit healthier (Though I think they taste very similar). This was very good when I tasted the original recipe, but I changed a few things so they were more like the sloppy joes I grew up with. I added a bit more mustard and just a touch of BBQ sauce for some spice. I did add about twice as much brown sugar, because I like my sloppy joes sweet. Otherwise, without modifications, it's great and very savory. With my alterations, it's a homemade classic that I had always looked forward to as a kid, but healthier.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a few times and my family always loves it. The last time I made it I didn't have any fresh vegatables on hand so I used about 2 TBSP freeze-dried bell peppers and about 2 TBSP dehydrated onions. Then I rehydrated them by soaking them in a bowl of water while the meat was browning & while I mixed the other sauce ingredients. After the meat was cooked I drained the excess water off the vegatables and dumped everything onto the meat in the pan and stirred it all together while everything finished thickening & warming together. It was fast, easy, and yummy.

userID:
5912271
Display Name:
Rani Ness
isPro:

10

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5831998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice! Not a sloppy Joe fan til NOW. Made triple batch in crockpot, using rather small minced cabbage for about a quarter of the hamburger. About 20 minutes before serving, it seemed a tiny bit too saucy, so, per advice of one reviewer, added just a touch of quick oats (no more than 3 Tbsp, but probably less). That took care of the tiny bit of juices that needed to be settled in, but when it came to dinner time, we couldn't tell any oats were added. Husband said he couldn't tell the cabbage was there. We agreed to try more cabbage next time due to the price of beef (might also try ground turkey & add twice the oats?). Raw sugar, not brown. Had no bell pepper, but doubled the onion. Added 3 cloves fresh garlic along with the onion, while still using powdered garlic. Ran out of ketchup, so used barbeque sauce for about half of the ketchup - would probably like more ketchup, the 2 parts ketchup to 1 part bbq suggested by other reviewers, but it was still very, very good.  Nice, flexible, easy recipe. Will try with all ketchup one of these days, I'm sure. My daughter came to say goodnight after brushing her teeth and saw the recipe and picture on this page while I was reviewing the recipe. She simply had to hover here a while just looking at the picture saying (several times while hugging my arm as I typed away), "I wanted to eat more, but I just couldn't. I was too stuffed.  We should have those every night!" Thanks, Tamara, for a success story from your kitchen to ours!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
9.25.13 ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/24264/sloppy-joes-ii/ ... 'Not a big fan of sloppy joes.  Guess it's because they were from a can when I was growing up.  These I can take!  :D  I had leftover (not very good because I used extra lean ground beef) meatloaf, about 2 & a half pounds.  I minced that & added a half cup sauteed onion, 15oz can tomato sauce, 3T brown sugar, 1/2t oregano, 1T chili powder, 1T yellow mustard & 1/4t red pepper.  I used fresh garlic with the onions.  No salt or pepper.  'Didn't need it.  'Could tell it was meatloaf makeover, but it was good.  The meatloaf was insanely big so I will follow this recipe again & with planned ground beef, too - or turkey! 9/13 I think we have a hit here. I subbed 1#mixed turkey w 1/2c minced onion, 1 minced carrot, 2cloves garlic, 15oz tomato sauce, 1T chili powder, 1T brown sugar, 1/2t dry mustard, 1/8t cayenne & 1/2t worcestershire. Pretty yummy & not too sweet or hot for all.  :o  :)

text:
I've made these twice.  The first time I tinkered too much with this great basic recipe.  The next I made only 2 changes.  I added minced, fresh garlic and took another reviewer's suggestion to use 1/2 of catsup and 1/4 cup barbeque sauce.  Mine was hickory flavored, I still added the mustard but not the garlic powder or brown sugar.  These sloppy joes satisfy my occasional cravings for 'kid's' food.  Thanks!

text:
I followed the recipe to a "T" and it was very good! I noticed that the sauce was slightly on the sweeter side after a few minutes of simmering so I had to add just a little water, nothing more. It was very tasty in toasted hamburger buns and served with buttered corn on the cob. nice!
02/19/15 This time I used ground turkey meat and a real garlic clove. I added 1/2 cup ketchup, a 1/2 c Sweet Baby Rays bbq sauce, a shot of Worcestershire sauce and a tsp of liquid smoke, and a tsp of vinegar for a little zing plus 1 more tsp brown sugar for balance and little water. I baked some buttermilk biscuits to place in the sloppy joes. For a side dish I baked some potato wedges. YUMMMY!!

text:
Pretty good for a quick meal.  I did find it a bit sweet for my liking and may omit the brown sugar completely next time.  I also added 1/2 cup of water during the simmering time.

I cut little caps out of the bun and removed some of the bun inside to make bowl, scooped the sloppy joe mixture into the bowl, topped with some cheddar cheese.  I stuck this under the broiler until the cheese was melted and stuck the cap back on the bun!  They weren't so sloppy after this.

text:
Great base recipe!  Made my own changes to make it a 5: (1) used ground turkey breast since had it on had and it was a great sub since the sauce added such a good flavor to usually dry meat. (2) cookede in all in a crock pot per other request and because I had such lean meat to help it not be so dry. (3) we like hotter-style food so I used the 3/4c. ketchup with the 20 oz. Gr. Turkey breast, upped the onion, pepper and used fresh garlic (so much better) and 2 Tbsp. Chipolte Tabasco to give it a kick with a good flavor.

It was good, but not the best Sloppy Joe I've had.  I thought it was a little sweet and not quite spicy enough.  Next time, I'll cut the brown sugar in 1/2, use only about 1/2 cup ketchup and add 1/4 cup BBQ sauce.  I would imagine if you use a brown sugar BBQ sauce, you could probably cut the brown sugar completely.

text:
This was a WONDERFUL recipe. Why the four stars? Because I did make some changes to make it the delectable dinner that it was. :) The changes I made were:
1. Added tomato sauce to the ketchup to make it a little more "sloppy." 
2. Used green, red, and orange peppers for extra color.
3. Added Emeril's southwest spice blend for extra kick.
This is not to say that the recipe would not have been great without these changes--just that to my eye/palate these modifications were a good idea. :)
Thanks for this recipe--it is a keeper!

i was nervous making this recipe because my boyfriend loves the Manwich Bold- i was afraid this wouldnt be as good since i've never made a sloppy joe before... wrong! he loved it! a few things i did differently: used 1 6oz. can tomato paste instead of ketchup, substituted Jack Daniels Original BBQ sauce instead of using the brown sugar (a couple glugs; eyeballed it), and added some chili pepper (about 1-2 Tspoons; again, eyeballed it)... came out great!  i am not big on exact-measure ingredients, so this recipe worked out well for that.

We really like these and Hubs polished off the little bit that was left in the pan, even without a bun!  Guess he must have liked it!

text:
I've been using this recipe for years and friends and family still get rave reviews.  There are only 2 changes that I make - I season the meat with garlic powder and black pepper while it's browning, and I omit the brown sugar and instead mix ketchup, mustard, and BBQ sauce in a bowl until it's at a color and consistency that I like, then I pour that into the pan.  The BBQ sauce adds a smokiness to it while not making it too sweet.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/255202.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I decided to try this for our family reunion tomorrow and scaled it for 60. I pretty much followed the recipe as written, but since I had to make such a large quantity, I browned the meat with pepper and onion in batches, adding them to the crockpot as they were done. Then used the same pan and made the sauce. Just brought it to a simmer so to break down the sugar. I did add about 3/4c bbq sauce in addition to the ketchup and a few dashes of worst sauce and one packet of McCormick Sloppy Joe seasoning (Only did this b/c I was such a huge amount - probably would only use a few tsp if it were standard size batch).  It is simmering in my crockpot right now and it is heavenly. I have to keep smacking hubby's hand b/c he keeps stealing bites here and there...might not be enough when I get done!  I'm so excited to bring it tomorrow.   Thank you for this fantastic recipe!

This was just okay in my opinion.  I prepared it exactly as written (minus brown sugar ... I used white sugar as that's all I had on hand).  Maybe the fact that I didn't use brown sugar made the difference, but it was too "ketchuppish" for my taste.  I don't care for ketchp to begin with but thought I'd try this out.  As someone else suggested, I added a half cup of water and a teaspoon of oatmeal to make it sticky ... didn't notice a difference at all.  I would make this again because it was good, but would probably modify it to my taste.

So, my son wanted sloppy joes for dinner. As soon as I put the meat in the skillet I realized that I forgot to buy sloppy joe mix. AR to the rescue! I used  approx 1/4 tsp onion powder (no onions), omitted the green peppers (yuck), and used approx 1/4 tsp minced garlic. I also threw in some soy sauce (nice dash or two) and approx 2 tbsp bbq sauce. Ended up adding maybe 1/4 cup water because it was a little too thick. Turned out great!

text:
With this recipe, I made mini sloppy joes for a cocktail party and they were a hit. Like other reviewers, I made slight adjustments by using less sugar (~1 tsp less), adding a few splashes of red wine vinegar, and adding ~1/2 cup of water. This is a keeper!

text:
Great recipe! New family favorite. I  made a few changes based our family's taste. I shredded carrots, added red onion, jalepeno, and chopped garlic. I used ground mustard, but I might also add dijon mustard next time. I also added worchester sauce, red pepper flakes, and cumin. I used tomatoe sauce and bbq sauce instead of ketchup. I did not use sugar.  Thanks for sharing this recipe. I vow to never use Manwich again.

text:
This was a great recipe. So simple to make yet so satisfying. I skipped the sugar since the ketchup I was using was sweet enough already, and unfortunately had no green bell peppers. We added freshly diced tomatoes (about 1/4 to 1/2 cup) in its place. Also used 1/2 lb of ground turkey instead of 1 lb of ground beef. But still, made 3 small sized open-faced sloppy joe sandwiches for me and 3 heaping large ones for my roommate. I think having the green bell peppers would have definitely given it that nice bitter flavor to add to it. We also added a teensy bit of thyme and fresh crushed oregano. YUM!! Would definitely make this again.

the ingredients in this recipe were great, but not nearly enough, and i did tweak them a bit. i used 1.15 lbs of lean ground beef and needed to double the sauce. i feel like it could have used one more dose of sauce.  i also added 2 t of minced garlic and 2 t of worcestershire sauce. cooked the beef in a skillet and then added everything to a slow cooker on simmer for 4 hours. so good.

text:
Very good- I think like others I can't resist making a few changes.  I added about 1/4 cup barbeque sauce that I had made a few days earlier, a diced roma tomato, and 1/2 a jalepeno.  I also didn't measure the garlic powder, but I'm sure it was more than was called for.  Also, since I am on a salt restricted diet I used no salt added Ketchup and did not add salt.  With all the other veggies and spices I didn't miss the salt.  My husband loved it and went back for seconds and thirds!  I loved this recipe!

text:
I grew up without ever eating sloppy joes. So when I had my first one I was excited. It was a Manwich and it was awful. I have never had one since. Now that I have two boys who have had sloppy joes at school (and loved them), I am on a hunt for a good recipe. This is it! I followed some other person's advice and only used 1/2 c ketchup and 1/4 c bbq sauce and omit the brown sugar. I pureed the onion and bell pepper in a blender before adding it to the beef. My boys don't like the veggie looking stuff so I had to be a little sneaky. I ate mine with toasted corn tortilla chips (kinda like a chili) and it was fabulous.

text:
This is a very tasty sloppy joe recipe. I have made it several times and the kids have asked if it is the recipe or the "store" kind. They are always excited when I tell them it is the homemade version. I wanted to give it a 4 1/2, but that is not an option. I think the taste is really good, but not "blow-me-a-way" good, but I gave it a 5 because I didn't think it only deserved a four. Just the right amount of spice and flavor. Would definitely be a good recipe to make for guests because nothing is too overpowering about the recipe. I have had some sloppy joes where it has a distinct mustard flavor...not my favorite! Have made this at least 3 times now.

text:
This was my first attempt at sloppy joes, and they were delicious!  I think the serving size is a bit misleading, because I had 1.25 lb of meat, and it only made 5 servings.  So adjust accordingly.  I omitted the green peppers, and slightly increased the amount of sauce, though I didn't completely double it.  So quick and easy, too!

text:
This was very good, simple and quick. I knew with a hungry husband and two fast growing teenage stepsons that one pound of ground beef would not go very far. I doubled the recipe, but used one pound of ground beef and one pound of country pork sausage. With the green bell pepper and onion I took the chopping a step further. The boys don't care for onion and pepper very much. I knew it would be good in it, so I pulverized it in my mini food processer. Blended it in the meat and they didn't even know it was there. They raved about it. It is gone!

text:
Excellent recipe!  Lean ground beef is best since it doesn't make the bread so soggy (and reduces the fat). The green pepper definitely made it!  Only changes I made were I added a little water during cooking since the mixture did run really thick.  I also added a few drops of Worcestershire sauce, extra garlic powder and black pepper.  I had leftover hotdog buns so I served them open faced with a knife and fork and a side of chips.  An instant hit!

text:
These sloppy joes were great! After browning the meat with the onions and peppers (to which I also added a shredded carrot), I combined the meat/veg with the sauce in the crockpot and put it on low for 3 hrs as suggested in another review.  I also modified the sauce - I added another 1/2 cup of ketchup, used about 2 tblspns mustard and brown sugar, upped the garlic powder to match, and used 2 tblspns bbq sauce, just to make it a little more saucy and a tad less ketchupy.
Review:

text:
Just made this for dinner tonight and it was a winner.  I did make a few changes suggested by other reviewers.  I used 1/2 cup of ketchup and 1/4 cup of BBQ sauce.  I also added 1/4 of diced red pepper which seemed to disappear along with the green pepper and onion after having cooked.  This was a good thing since the husband isn't so keen on peppers.  LOL  I added about 1/2 tsp of onion salt instead of plain salt and also added 1 1/2tsp of hickory liquid smoke.  Super Sloppy Sandwich served with coleslaw made for a wonderful meal.  Thanks.

text:
So easy to make and much more tasty than the can (and cheaper since you usually have the ingredients around the house).  Like others, I did make a few modifications.  I increased the onions and green peppers to 1/2 cup and sprinkled garlic salt and pepper on the meat while browning.  I also added a little (about 2 tbsp) BBQ sauce and found the need to add a little water to the mixture while it was simmering.  It was perfect!  I will never use the canned stuff again!!!

I've made this recipe a few times, and every time it's turned out great. I've done it strictly as the recipe says and it turns out just fine, and I've also added in various things that me and my fiancee like or increased some things (like the amount of onions) depending on our own preferences. Either way, the recipe is worth a 5. I would note, however, that for me and my fiancee increasing the recipe to 8-12 servings (1 1/2 - 2lb of beef) is just about right for us, as 1lb doesn't seem like enough for two.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had my doubts about the mustard in this recipe, but the combination of flavors was really quite good.  I doubled the recipe except for the green pepper (because I didn't have much) and cut the brown sugar by about 1/3.  The full amount of brown sugar would have made the recipe too sweet, IMO.  This is a good recipe if you like to pick up your sloppy joes and eat them in the bun.  If you prefer to eat them open-faced, you might want to add some water to make more sauce.  I also like the fact that it's a tasty homemade sauce without the additives that come with the prepared sauces.

Best recipe for these by far!

WOW! I stumbled upon this recipe out of sheer luck. Since I'm in college, and I only had a few things on hand, I was looking for an easy recipe involving ground beef. My first thought was meatloaf, but I had no eggs, and then I found this bad boy. Sloppy Joes are one of my favorites and I have never tried making them from scratch. THIS IS ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS. I don't think I'm ever making another canned version - you can really taste the layers of flavors in this one. 
The only thing I chose to add were:
1 tbs of worsticher sauce (I know I spelled that wrong)

about a tsp of cumin.
Fantastic! Not only was it delicious, but  easy and quick. I will definitely be making this again !!!

userID:
1709686
Display Name:
Jaay
isPro:
False
followersCount:
15
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
119
favoritesCount:
3053
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/66974.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a few changes so I'm only giving the original recipe a 4.  With the few changes I would rate ir a 4.5 - 5.  The recipe was great and it will definitely be a repeat for us.  It was easy didn't require alot of multi-tasking which I love.  I made the recipe as instructed, but felt like it needed a few more things once I got it into the pan, so in the end I used about 1 c. of ketchup total and because it didn't seem juicy enough I added about a 1/2 c. of water.  We really didn't taste the bell pepper at all, so perhaps I should have cut it into larger chunks or just omit it next time.  The flavor wasn't lacking without the bell pepper.  It was a little sweet, so next time I'll either cut back on the brown sugar a bit, or add a little more mustard.

I served these with roasted potato chunks seasoned with seasoning salt.  A perfect accompaniment.  I'll probably double the recipe next time and put a container in the freezer for later.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-03-30T18:18:25.24
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I'm only giving this three stars because I had to do quite a bit of tweaking to get it right for my taste.  As a base for making sloppy joes your 'own' (without the help of Manwich) it's okay.  It was a little too dry and crumbly for my family.  Since first using this recipe, I double it now and I actually use one can of Manwich (can't believe I'm admitting that) just for the sloppy factor and then add ketchup, mustard, brown sugar, etc. (The brown sugar is the key to this recipe, so whatever changes you make, don't skip the sugar, if anything add a little more!)

This is a really good recipe! I used ground turkey instead of ground beef to make it lower in fat.  I used half a red onion, half a green pepper, and a diced tomato. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made 3 servings worth of the Sloppy Joes (I cut the recommended servings in half).  It was a tasty and easy recipe, but a few things:

It was a bit sweet as others had stated, so I added about 1/2 tablespoon of soy sauce to mellow out the sweetness and to give it more flavor.  

It was pretty thick, so I added a full cup of water--the mixture sucked it right up and it became more "sloppy" as I like it not so thick.

I like to eat veggies so I added more veggies than the portion called for and added 1/2 onion and one whole green bell pepper in with the ground beef. My fiancee told me that sloppy joes usually dont have much veggies in it, but I felt it didnt hurt the recipe (although, that may not have been the point :D  )  

I was very surprised at the taste of the dish with so few ingredients.  Thank you for the recipe.

text:
This is the best, easiest recipe. This was my first time making sloppy joe and I thoroughly enjoyed it. My boyfriend is a picky eater and a great chef so it's hard to show him up. He asked for seconds! We will definitely make this again.
I used red peppers and had to add extra sauce because it wasn't sloppy enough. I ended up using BBQ sauce because I ran out of ketchup and it was still lovely. I added onion powder, chili powder, and a little more peppers to balance out the flavor. I also used  ground turkey for health reasons. We used wheat bread and had green beans on the side. Enjoy!

I've made sloppy joes from a generic brand can a couple times and they weren't popular with my family.  This was much better.  A little sweet for our tastes, we will use half the  brown sugar next time.  I'll definately keep this recipe around for when  quick meal is required.  I made some with "soy ground beef crumbles" as well for our vegetarian daughter.  I served these on fresh whole wheat kaiser rolls with coleslaw on the side.

I haven't eaten this on a bun yet, but it already tastes pretty good.  I was really short on time, and had a lack of ideas for dinner, and this seemed the perfect solution.  I did add a couple of globs of BBQ sauce and I think it might have pretty much ruined the original flavor which was great, but tasted like mustard, which I cannot stand.  So, I think it probably tasted a little better without the BBQ sauce( it's overpowering), but it's still yummy tasting.  I added 1/2 c. water and a 1 T. of quick oats as per other reviews suggested.  I'm excited for dinner!  Thanks for the recipe!

A much better solution for sloppy joes than the canned sauces available in grocery stores!

text:
Sensational! These are great. I've made them twice, and, like some others, the second time I left out the brown sugar and reduced the ketchup to 1/2 cup. I also added 1/2 t chili powder. The first time I made these, I had to keep them warm until my hubby got home from work, so I continually added beef broth while it simmered. OUTSTANDING!!! I am so glad I found this recipe. We pile the meat up on ours, so 1lb of beef ususally gives us 2 or 3 sandwiches (depending on how greedy everybody is at the time!). I really don't think this recipe NEEDS the brown sugar, but have some on hand because you may like it with it in there. I usually just serve these on buns, but another reviewer mentioned broiling them with cheese...HELLO! I'm gonna try that! I definitely prefer this over Manwich in a can with artificial everything, chemical preservatives, and Heaven knows what else! Thank you so much for sharing this!

I followed the recipe exactly although I used ground turkey instead of beef.  Pretty good but not the best I've ever had.  I do think the sauce would have went better with beef. text:
this was awesome. but i did make few alterations. instead of using ground beef i used packaged italian meatballs that come frozen. frozen italian meatballs are made seasoned already so all you have to do is heat them up and ground them. i used white sugar instead of brown and i added water like one reviewer suggested to reach my desired "sloppy" consistency. i also added no salt because the ketchup and frozen meatballs have salt in them already; adding more salt is unnecessary. i've never made sloppy joes before and it was so easy. it will definitely be a regular selection for dinner. thanx.

I enjoyed this recipe very much and only made a couple of minor changes - I added some garlic cloves instead of garlic powder and I ended up adding a small amount of tomato paste.  I had not had sloppy joes in years and thought that it needed a stronger "tomato taste", hence the tomato paste.  My husband absolutely loved them - I will definitely be making them again.  Thanks for such a terrific recipe!

text:
Yumm. It was very good. I added Worcestershire sauce to my meat while it was cooking because I like the taste of it. I used a clove of garlic, because all I had was garlic salt and I didn't want to make it too salty. At the end, I decided to add a few dollops of bbq sauce to add a smoked taste. 

Over all really good. I thought it was a tiny bit sweet. But that would be my fault. I had 1 1/2 lbs. of meat so I increased my ingredients. Next time I'll leave the sugar alone. Either way it was yummy and I'll use this recipe every time I make sloppy joes.

text:
Very Good!  I didn't have any green peppers on hand so I added a few jarred jalapeno pepper rings and chopped them up(approx. a tspn)and added them to the pan which gave it a nice bite.  I also felt as though it was missing a little something at the very end so, I decided to add a tad more of ketchup and a teaspoon of pure 100% maple syrup.  That was the ticket!!!!  After that, it was soooooooo good!  I give this recipe 4 stars for what it tasted like before I added the maple syrup, but I'd give it 5 stars afterwards!!!!

I would not make these again.  First of all, they were way too garlicky even though I halved the amount of garlic powder.  I didn't think the sauce had enough flavor, so I kept adding things to try to improve it.  I added some Worcestershire sauce and even a little dry mustard to try to give it more kick.  Eventually they turned out okay, but I would look for a different recipe the next time I wanted Sloppy Joes.

text:
I made these for lunch today along with the oven roasted potatoes from this site and my husband said "Wow!  These are the best sloppy joes you have ever made!"  And I totally agree with him.  Even my picky 5 year old who never likes anything ate her entire sandwich (a once a month feat) and asked for more. I did leave out the onions and peppers since my husband and daughter don't really like them and I didn't use any salt or pepper.  I also doubled the sauce and I'm glad I did since I think they would have been too dry if I hadn't.  They were great this way, and so easy to make too!

I was also in a crunch for time so I made it about noon, and simmered it in the crock pot until serving time.  This one's a keeper!!!
